books.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:1
verses.text: Register of the Epistles of Saint Gregory the Great.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:2
verses.text: Book I.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:3
verses.text: The Month of September, Indiction IX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:4
verses.text: , Being the First Year of His Ordination.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:5
verses.text: Epistle I.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:6
verses.text: To all the Bishops of Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:7
verses.text: Gregory, servant of the servants of God, to all the bishops constituted throughout Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:8
verses.text: We have plainly perceived it to be very necessary that, even as our predecessors thought fit to do, we should commit all things to one and the same person; and that, where we cannot be present ourselves, our authority should be represented through him to whom we send our instructions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:9
verses.text: Wherefore, with the help of God, we have appointed Peter, subdeacon of our See, our delegate in the province of Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:10
verses.text: Nor can we doubt as to the conduct of him to whom, with the help of God, we are known to have committed the charge of the whole patrimony of our church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:11
verses.text: This also we have plainly perceived to be a thing that ought to be done; that once in the year your whole fraternity should assemble, at Syracuse or Catana, receiving, as we have charged him, the honour due to you; to the end that, together with the aforesaid Peter, subdeacon of our See, you may settle with due discretion whatever things pertain to the advantage of the churches of the province, or to the relief of the necessities of the poor and oppressed, or to the admonition of all, and the correction of those whose transgressions may peradventure be proved.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:12
verses.text: From which council far be animosities, which are the nutriment of crimes, and may inward grudges die away, and that discord of souls which is beyond measure execrable.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:13
verses.text: Let concord well-pleasing to God, and charity, approve you as His priests.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 1:14
verses.text: Conduct all things, therefore, with such deliberation and calmness that yours may most worthily be called an Episcopal Council.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:1
verses.text: Epistle II.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:2
verses.text: To Justinus, Praetor of Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:3
verses.text: Gregory to Justinus, Praetor of Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:4
verses.text: What my tongue speaks my conscience approves; since even before you had become engaged in the employments of any office of dignity, I have greatly loved and greatly respected you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:5
verses.text: For the very modesty of your deportment made certain incipient claims on affection even from one who had been loth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:6
verses.text: And, when I heard that you had come to administer the praetorship of Sicily, I greatly rejoiced.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:7
verses.text: But, since I have discovered that a certain ill-feeling is creeping in between you and the ecclesiastics, I have been exceedingly distressed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:8
verses.text: But now that you are occupied with the charge of civil administration, and I with the care of this ecclesiastical government, we can properly love one another in particular so far as we do no harm to the general community.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:9
verses.text: Wherefore I beseech you by Almighty God, before Whose tremendous judgment we must give account of our deeds, that your Glory have always the fear of Him before your eyes, and never allow anything to come in whereby even slight dissension may arise between us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:10
verses.text: Let no gains draw you aside to injustice; let not either the threats or the favours of any one cause you  to deviate from the path of rectitude.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:11
verses.text: See how short life is: think, ye that exercise judicial authority, before what judge ye must at some time go.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:12
verses.text: It is therefore to be diligently considered that we shall leave all gains behind us here, and that of harmful gains we shall carry with us to the judgment the pleas only that are against us for them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:13
verses.text: Those advantages, then, are to be sought by us which death may in no wise take away, but which the end of the present life may shew to be such as will endure for ever.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:14
verses.text: As to what you write concerning the corn, the magnificent Citonatus asserts very differently that no more has been transmitted than what was supplied for replenishing the public granary in satisfaction of what was due for the past indiction.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:15
verses.text: Give attention to this matter, since, if what is transmitted be at all defective, it will be the death not of any one single person only, but of the whole people together.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:16
verses.text: Now for the management of the patrimony of Sicily I have sent, as I think under the guidance of God, such a man as you will be in entire accord with, if you are a lover of what is right, as I have found you to be.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 2:17
verses.text: Moreover, as to your desire that I should remember you kindly, I confess the truth when I say that, unless any injustice should creep in from the snares of the ancient foe, I have learnt thy Glory's modesty to be such that I shah not blush to be thy friend.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3:1
verses.text: Epistle III.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3:2
verses.text: To Paul, Scholasticus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3:3
verses.text: Gregory to Paul, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3:4
verses.text: However strangers smile upon me on account of the dignity of my priestly office, this I take not much account of; but I do grieve not a little at your smiling upon me on this account, seeing that you know what I long for, and yet suppose me to have received advancement.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3:5
verses.text: For to me it would have been the highest advancement, if what I wished could have been fulfilled; if I could have accomplished my desire, which you have been long acquainted with, in the enjoyment of longed-for rest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3:6
verses.text: Yet, since I am now detained in the city of Rome, tied by the chains of this dignity, I have something wherein I may even rejoice in addressing your Glory, seeing that, when the most eminent lord the ex-consul Leo comes, I suspect that you will not remain in Sicily; and when thou thyself also, tied by thine own dignity, shalt come to be detained in Rome, thou wilt come to know what sorrow and what bitterness I suffer.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3:7
verses.text: But when the magnificent Lord Maurentius, the Chartularius, comes to you, I pray thee concur with him in regard to the present straits of the Roman city, since outside we are stabbed without cease by hostile swords.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3:8
verses.text: But we are still more heavily pressed by danger within through a sedition of the soldiers.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 3:9
verses.text: Further, we commend to your Glory in all respects Peter our sub-deacon, whom we have sent to rule the patrimony of the Church.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 4

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 4:1
verses.text: Epistle IV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 4:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 4:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 4:4
verses.text: If the virtue of charity consists in the love of one's neighbour, and we are commanded to love our neighbours as ourselves, how is it that your Blessedness does not love me even as yourself? For I know with what ardour, with what anxiety, you wished to fly from the burden of the episcopate; and yet you made no opposition to this same burden of the episcopate being imposed on me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 4:5
verses.text: It is evident, then, that you do not love me as yourself, seeing that you have wished me to take on myself that load which you were unwilling should be imposed on you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 4:6
verses.text: But since I, unworthy and weak, have taken charge of an old and grievously shattered ship (for on all sides the waves enter, and the planks, battered by a daily and violent storm, sound of shipwreck), I beseech thee by Almighty God to stretch out the hand of thy prayer to me in this my danger, since thou canst pray the more strenuously as thou standest further removed from the confusion of the tribulations which we suffer in this land.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 4:7
verses.text: My synodical epistle I will transmit with all possible speed, having despatched Bacauda, our brother and fellow-bishop, immediately after my ordination, as the bearer of this letter, while pressed by many and serious engagements.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:1
verses.text: Epistle V.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:2
verses.text: To Theoctista, Sister of the Emperor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:3
verses.text: Gregory to Theoctista, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:4
verses.text: With how great devotion my mind prostrates itself before your Venerableness I cannot fully express in words; nor yet do I labour to give utterance to it, since, even though I were silent, you read in your heart your own sense  of my devotion.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:5
verses.text: I wonder, however, that you withdrew your countenance, till of late bestowed on me, from this my recent engagement in the pastoral office; wherein, under colour of episcopacy, I have been brought back to the world; in which I am involved in such great earthly cares as I do not at all remember having been subjected to even in a lay state of life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:6
verses.text: For I have lost the deep joys of my quiet, and seem to have risen outwardly while inwardly falling down.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:7
verses.text: Whence I grieve to find myself banished far from the face of my Maker.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:8
verses.text: For I used to strive daily to win my way outside the world, outside the flesh; to drive all phantasms of the body from the eyes of my soul, and to see incorporeally supernal joys; and not only with my voice but in the core of my heart I used to say, My heart hath said unto Thee, I have sought Thy face, Thy face, Lord, will I seek (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:9
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:10
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:11
verses.text: Moreover desiring nothing, fearing nothing, in this world, I seemed to myself to stand on a certain summit of things, so that I almost believed to be fulfilled in me what I had learnt of the Lord's promise through the prophet, I will lift thee up upon the high places of the earth (Isai.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:12
verses.text: lviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:13
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:14
verses.text: For he is lifted up upon the high places of the earth who treads under foot through looking down upon them in his mind even the very things of the present world which seem lofty and glorious.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:15
verses.text: But, having been suddenly dashed from this summit of things by the whirlwind of this trial, I have fallen into fears and tremors, since, even though I have no fears for myself, I am greatly afraid for those who have been committed to me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:16
verses.text: On every side I am tossed by the waves of business, and sunk by storms, so that I may truly say, I am come into the depth of the sea, and the storm hath overwhelmed me (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:17
verses.text: lxviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:18
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:19
verses.text: After business I long to return to my heart; but, driven therefrom by vain tumults of thoughts, I am unable to return.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:20
verses.text: From this cause, then, that which is within me is made to be far from me, so that I cannot obey the prophetic voice which says, Return to your heart, transgressors (Isai.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:21
verses.text: xlvi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:22
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:23
verses.text: But, pressed by foolish thoughts, I am impelled only to exclaim, My heart hath failed me (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:24
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:25
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:26
verses.text: I have loved the beauty of the contemplative life as a Rachel, barren, but keen of sight and fair (Gen.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:27
verses.text: xxix.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:28
verses.text: ), who, though in her quietude she is less fertile, yet sees the light more keenly.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:29
verses.text: But, by what judgment I know not, Leah has been coupled with me in the night, to wit, the active life; fruitful, but tender-eyed; seeing less, but bringing forth more.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:30
verses.text: I have longed to sit at the feet of the Lord with Mary, to take in the words of His mouth; and lo, I am compelled to serve with Martha in external affairs, to be careful and troubled about many things (Luke x.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:31
verses.text: 39, seq.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:32
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:33
verses.text: A legion of demons having been, as I believed, cast out of me, I wished to forget those whom I had known, and to rest at the feet of the Saviour; and lo it is said to me, so as to compel me against my will, Return to thine house, and declare how great things the Lord hath done for thee (Mark v.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:34
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:35
verses.text: But who in the midst of so many earthly cares may be able to preach the wondrous works of God, it being already difficult for me even to call them to mind? For, pressed as I am in this office of dignity by a crowd of secular occupations, I see myself to be of those of whom it is written, While they were being raised up thou didst cast them down (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:36
verses.text: lxxii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:37
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:38
verses.text: For he said not, Thou didst cast them down after they had been raised up, but while they were being raised up; because all bad men fall inwardly, while through the support of temporal dignity they seem outwardly to rise.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:39
verses.text: Wherefore their very raising up is their fall, because, while they rely on false glory, they are emptied of true glory.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:40
verses.text: Hence, again, he says, Consuming away as smoke shall they consume away (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:41
verses.text: xxxvi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:42
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:43
verses.text: For smoke in rising consumes away, and in extending itself vanishes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:44
verses.text: And so indeed it comes to pass when present felicity accompanies the life of a sinner, since whereby he is shewn to be exalted, thereby it is brought about that he should cease to be.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:45
verses.text: Hence, again, it is written, My God, make them like a wheel (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:46
verses.text: lxxxii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:47
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:48
verses.text: For a wheel is lifted up in its hinder parts, and in its fore parts falls.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:49
verses.text: But to us the things that are behind are the goods of the present world, which we leave behind us; but the things that are before are those which are eternal and permanent, to which we are called, as Paul bears witness, saying, Forgetting those things which are behind, and reaching forth to those things which are before (Phil.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:50
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:51
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:52
verses.text: The sinner, therefore, when he is advanced in the present life, is made to be as a wheel, since, while falling in the things which are before, he is lifted up in the things which are behind.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:53
verses.text: For, when he enjoys in this life the glory which he must leave behind, he falls from that which comes after this life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:54
verses.text: There are indeed many who know how so to control their outward advancement as by no means to fall inwardly thereby.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:55
verses.text: Whence it is written, God casteth not away the mighty, seeing that He also Himself is mighty (Job xxxvi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:56
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:57
verses.text: And it is said through Solomon,  A man of understanding shall possess governments (Prov.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:58
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:59
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:60
verses.text: But to me these things are difficult, since they are also exceedingly burdensome; and what the mind has not received willingly it does not control fitly.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:61
verses.text: Lo, our most serene Lord the Emperor has ordered an ape to be made a lion.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:62
verses.text: And, indeed, in virtue of his order it can be called a lion, but a lion it cannot be made.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 5:63
verses.text: Wherefore his Piety must needs himself take the blame of all my faults and short-comings, having committed a ministry of power to a weak agent.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:1
verses.text: Epistle VI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:2
verses.text: To Narses, Patrician.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:3
verses.text: Gregory to Narses, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:4
verses.text: In describing loftily the sweetness of contemplation, you have renewed the groans of my fallen state, since I hear what I have lost inwardly while mounting outwardly, though undeserving, to the topmost height of rule.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:5
verses.text: Know then that I am stricken with so great sorrow that I can scarcely speak; for the dark shades of grief block up the eyes of my soul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:6
verses.text: Whatever is beheld is sad, whatever is thought delightful appears to my heart lamentable.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:7
verses.text: For I reflect to what a dejected height of external advancement I have mounted in falling from the lofty height of my rest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:8
verses.text: And, being sent for my faults into the exile of employment from the face of my Lord, I say with the prophet, in the words, as it were of destroyed Jerusalem, He who should comfort me hath departed far from me (Lam.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:9
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:10
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:11
verses.text: But when, in seeking a similitude to express my condition and title, you frame periods and declamations in your letter, certainly, dearest brother, you call an ape a lion.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:12
verses.text: Herein we see that you do as we often do, when we call mangy whelps pards or tigers.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:13
verses.text: For I, my good man, have, as it were, lost my children, since through earthly cares I have lost works of righteousness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:14
verses.text: Therefore call me not Noemi, that is fair; but call me Mara, for I am full of bitterness (Ruth i.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:15
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:16
verses.text: But as to your saying that I ought not to have written, "That you should plough with bubaliin the Lord's field," seeing that when in the sheet shewn to the blessed Peter both bubali and all wild beasts were presented to view; thou knowest thyself that it is subjoined, Slay and eat (Acts x.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:17
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:18
verses.text: Thou, then, who hadst not yet slain these beasts, why didst thou already wish to eat them through obedience? Or knowest thou not that the beast about which thou wrotest refused to be slain by the sword of thy mouth? Thou must needs, then, satisfy the hunger of thy desire with those whom thou hast been able to prick and slay (Lit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:19
verses.text: , to slay through compunction).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:20
verses.text: Further, as to the case of our brethren, I think that, if God gives aid, it will be as thou hast written.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:21
verses.text: It was not, however, by any means right for me to write about it at present to our most serene lords, since at the very outset one should not begin with complaints.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:22
verses.text: But I have written to my well-beloved son, the deacon Honoratus, that he should mention the matter to them in a suitable manner at a seasonable time, and speedily inform me of their reply.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 6:23
verses.text: I beg greetings to be given in my behalf to the lord Alexander, the lord Theodorus, my son Marinus, the lady Esicia, the lady Eudochia, and the lady Dominica.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:1
verses.text: Epistle VII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:2
verses.text: To Anastasius, Patriarch of Antioch.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:3
verses.text: Gregory to Anastasius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:4
verses.text: I have found what your Blessedness has written to be as rest to the weary, as health to the sick, as a fountain to the thirsty, as shade to the oppressed with heat.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:5
verses.text: For those words of yours did not seem even to be expressed by the tongue of the flesh, inasmuch as you so disclosed the spiritual love which you bear me as if your soul itself were speaking.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:6
verses.text: But very hard was that which followed, in that your love enjoined me to bear earthly burdens, and that, having first loved me spiritually, you  afterwards, loving me as I think in temporal wise, pressed me down to the ground with the burden you laid upon me; so that, losing utterly all uprightness of soul, and forfeiting the keen vision of contemplation, I may say, not in the spirit of prophecy, but from experience, I am bowed down and brought low altogether (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:7
verses.text: cxviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:8
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:9
verses.text: For indeed such great burdens of business press me down that my mind can in no wise lift itself up to heavenly things.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:10
verses.text: I am tossed by the billows of a multitude of affairs, and, after the ease of my former quiet, am afflicted by the storms of a tumultuous life, so that I may truly say, I am come into the depth of the sea, and the storm hath overwhelmed me (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:11
verses.text: lxviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:12
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:13
verses.text: Stretch out, therefore, the hand of your prayer to me in my danger, you that stand on the shore of virtue.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:14
verses.text: But as to your calling me the mouth and the lantern of the Lord, and alleging that I profit many, this also adds to the load of my iniquities, that, when my iniquity ought to have been chastised, I receive praises instead of chastisement.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:15
verses.text: But with what a bustle of earthly business I am distracted in this place, I cannot express in words; yet you can gather it from the shortness of this letter, in which I say so little to him who I love above all others.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 7:16
verses.text: Further, I apprize you that I have requested our most serene lords with all possible urgency to allow you to come to the threshold of Peter, the prince of the apostles, with your dignity restored to you, and to live here with me so long as it may please God; to the end that, as long as I am accounted worthy of seeing you, we may relieve the weariness of our pilgrimage by speaking to each other of the heavenly country.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:1
verses.text: Epistle IX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:2
verses.text: To Peter the Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:4
verses.text: Gregory, a servant of God, presbyter and abbot of the monastery of Saint Theodore in the province of Sicily constituted in the territory of Panormus, has given us to understand that men of the farm of Fulloniacus, which belongs to the holy Roman Church, are endeavouring to encroach on the boundaries of the farm of Gerdinia, bordering on the said farm of the holy Roman Church, which they [i-e: monks of St.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:5
verses.text: Theodore] have possessed without dispute for innumerable years.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:6
verses.text: And for this cause we desire you to go to the city of Panormus, and investigate the question in such sort (with the view of the right of possession remaining with those who have had it heretofore) that, if you shall find that the aforesaid monastery of Saint Theodore has possessed the boundaries concerning which the dispute has arisen without disturbance for forty years, you shall not allow it to suffer any damage, even though it were to the advantage of the holy Roman Church, but provide in all ways for its undisturbed security.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:7
verses.text: But, if the agents of the holy Roman Church should shew that the monastery has not been in possession without dispute of its right for forty years, but that any question has been raised within that time concerning the said boundaries, let it be set at rest peaceably and legally by arbitrators chosen for the purpose.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:8
verses.text: For not only do we wish that questions of wrong-doing that have never yet been mooted should be raised, but also that such as have been raised by others than ourselves should be speedily set at rest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:9
verses.text: Let thy experience, therefore, cause all to be so effectively adjusted, that no question relating to this matter may be hereafter referred to us again.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:10
verses.text: Further, we desire that the testament of Bacauda, late Xenodochus, continue valid as when first made.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 8:11
verses.text: The month of November: ninth Indiction.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 9

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 9:1
verses.text: Epistle X.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 9:2
verses.text: To Bacauda and Agnellus, Bishops.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 9:3
verses.text: Gregory to Bacauda, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 9:4
verses.text: The Hebrews dwelling in Terracina have petitioned us for licence to hold, under our authority, the site of their synagogue which they have held hitherto.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 9:5
verses.text: But, inasmuch as we have been informed that the same site is so near to the church that even the sound of their psalmody reaches it, we have written to our brother and fellow-bishop Peter that, if it is the case that the voices from the said place are heard in the church, the Jews must cease to worship there.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 9:6
verses.text: Therefore let your Fraternity, with our above-named brother and fellow-bishop, diligently inspect this place, and if you find that there has been any annoyance to the church, provide another place within the fortress, where the aforesaid Hebrews may assemble, so that they may be able to celebrate their ceremonies without impediment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 9:7
verses.text: But let your Fraternity provide such a place, in case of their being deprived of this one, that there be no cause of complaint in future.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 9:8
verses.text: But we forbid the aforesaid Hebrews to be oppressed or vexed unreasonably; but,  as they are permitted, in accordance with justice, to live under the protection of the Roman laws, let them keep their observances as they have learnt them, no one hindering them: yet let it not be allowed them to have Christian slaves.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10:1
verses.text: Epistle XI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10:2
verses.text: To Clementina, Patrician.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10:3
verses.text: Gregory to Clementina, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10:4
verses.text: Having received your Glory's letter speaking of the passing away of the late Eutherius of magnificent memory, we give you to understand that our mind no less than yours is disturbed by such a sorrow, in that we see how men of approved repute are by degrees removed from this world, whose ruin is already evidenced in the actual effects of the causes thereof.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10:5
verses.text: But it becomes us to withdraw ourselves from it by the wise precaution of conversion, lest it involve us too in its own ruin.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10:6
verses.text: And indeed our sorrow for the loss of friends ought to be the more tolerable as our condition of mortality requires from us that we should lose them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10:7
verses.text: Nevertheless, for the loss of aid to our carnal life He Who granted permission for its removal is powerful to console, and to come Himself as a comforter into the vacant place.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10:8
verses.text: That we are unable to accede to your request that the deacon Anatholius should be sent to you is due to the circumstances of the case, and not to any rigorous austerity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 10:9
verses.text: For we have appointed him our steward, having committed our episcopal residence to his management.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 11

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 11:1
verses.text: Epistle XII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 11:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop of Urbs Vetus (Orvieto).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 11:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 11:4
verses.text: Agapitus, abbot of the monastery of St.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 11:5
verses.text: George, informs us that he endures many grievances from your Holiness; and not only in things that might be of service to the monastery in time of need, but that you even prohibit the celebration of masses in the said monastery, and also interdict burial of the dead there.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 11:6
verses.text: Now, if this is so, we exhort you to desist from such inhumanity, and allow the dead to be buried, and masses to be celebrated there without any further opposition, lest the aforesaid venerable Agapitus should be compelled to complain anew concerning the matters referred to.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 12

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 12:1
verses.text: Epistle XVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 12:2
verses.text: To Severus, Bishop of Aquileia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 12:3
verses.text: Gregory to Severus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 12:4
verses.text: As, when one who walks through devious ways takes anew the right path, the Lord embraces him with all eagerness, so afterwards, when one deserts the way of truth, He is more saddened with grief for him than He rejoiced over him with joy when he turned from error; since it is a less degree of sin not to know the truth than not to abide in it when known: and what is committed in error is one thing, but what is perpetrated knowingly is another.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 12:5
verses.text: And we, from having formerly rejoiced in thy being incorporated in the unity of the Church, are now the more abundantly distressed for thy dissociation from the catholic society.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 12:6
verses.text: Accordingly we desire thee, at the instance of the bearer of these presents, according to the command of the most Christian and most serene Emperor, to come with thy adherents to the threshold of the blessed Apostle Peter, that, a synod being assembled by the will of God, judgment may be passed concerning the doubt that is entertained among you.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 13

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 13:1
verses.text: Epistle XVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 13:2
verses.text: To all the Bishops of Italy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 13:3
verses.text: Gregory to all, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 13:4
verses.text: Inasmuch as the abominable Autharit during this Easter solemnity which has been lately completed, forbade children of Lombards being baptized in the catholic faith, for which sin the Divine Majesty cut him off, so that he should not see the solemnity of another Easter, it becomes your Fraternity to warn all the Lombards in your districts, seeing that grievous mortality is everywhere  imminent, that they should reconcile these their children who have been baptized in Arian heresy to the catholic faith, and so appease the wrath of the Almighty Lord which hangs over them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 13:5
verses.text: Warn, then, those whom you can; with all the power of persuasion you possess seize on them, and bring them to a right faith; preach to them eternal life without end; that, when you shall come into the sight of the strict judge, you may be able, in consequence of your solicitude, to shew in your own persons a shepherd's gains.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:1
verses.text: Epistle XVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:2
verses.text: To Peter the Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:4
verses.text: We have been informed that Marcellus of the Barutanian Church, who has had penance assigned him in the monastery of Saint Adrian in the same city of Panormus, not only is in want of food, but also suffers inconvenience from scarcity of clothing.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:5
verses.text: Therefore we hold it necessary to enjoin your Activity by this present order to appoint for him as much as you may see to be needful in the way of food, clothing and bedding for his own maintenance, and provision for his servant; so that his want and nakedness may be provided for with such timely care that what you assign to this same man may be reckoned afterwards to your own account.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:6
verses.text: So act, therefore, that you may both fulfil our command, and also by ordering this very thing well you may be able yourself to partake of the profit of the same.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:7
verses.text: Further, there is this other matter that we enjoin you to look to without regard to the old custom that has now grown up; namely, that if any cities in the province of Sicily, for their sins, are known to be without pastoral government through the lapses of their priests, you should see whether there be any worthy of the office of priesthood among the clergy of the churches themselves, or out of the monasteries, and, after first enquiring into the gravity of their behaviour, send them to us, that the flock of each place may not be found destitute for any length of time through the lapse of its pastor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:8
verses.text: But if you should discover any vacant place in which no one of the same church is found fitted for such a dignity, send us word after the like careful enquiry, that some one may be provided whom God may have judged worthy of such ordination.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:9
verses.text: For it is not right that from the deviation of one the Lord's flock should be in danger of wandering abroad among precipices without a shepherd.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 14:10
verses.text: For thus both the administration of places will go on, and there will remain no suspicion of the lapsed being restored to their former rank; and so may they repent the better.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 15

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 15:1
verses.text: Epistle XIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 15:2
verses.text: To Natalis, Bishop of Salona.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 15:3
verses.text: Gregory to Natalis, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 15:4
verses.text: The acts of your synod which you have transmitted to us, in which the Archdeacon Honoratus is condemned, we perceive to be full of the seed of strifes, seeing that the same person is at one and the same time advanced to the dignity of the priesthood against his will, and removed from the office of the diaconate as though unworthy of it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 15:5
verses.text: And, as it is just that no one who is unwilling should be advanced by compulsion, so I think we must be of opinion that no one who is innocent should be deposed from the ministry of his order unjustly.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 15:6
verses.text: Nevertheless, since discord hateful to God excuses thy part in the transaction, we admonish thee to restore his place and administration to the Archdeacon Honoratus, and agree to supply him with attendance sufficient for his divine ministry.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 15:7
verses.text: If cause of offence is still fomented between you, let the aforesaid Archdeacon submit himself to our audience and enquiry, when admonished to do so, and let thy love send to us a person instructed in the case, that in the presence of both, the Lord assisting us, we may be able to decide what justice approves without respect of persons.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 16

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 16:1
verses.text: Epistle XX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 16:2
verses.text: To Honoratus, Deacon of Salona.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 16:3
verses.text: Gregory to Honoratus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 16:4
verses.text: Having read the contradictory letters which thou and thy bishop have addressed to us against each other, we grieve that there is so little charity between you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 16:5
verses.text: Nevertheless we enjoin thee to continue in the administration of thy office, and, if the cause of offence between you can, under the power of grace, be settled on the spot, we believe it will be  greatly to the advantage of your souls.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 16:6
verses.text: But in case the discord between you has so set you in arms against each other that you have no will to allay the swelling of your offence, do thou without delay come to be heard before us, and let thy bishop send to us on his own behalf such person as he may choose, furnished with instructions; that, after minutely considering the whole case, we may settle what may appear fit between the parties.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 16:7
verses.text: But we would have thee know that we shall make strict enquiry of thee on all points, as to whether the ornaments, either those of thine own church, or such as have been collected from various churches, are being now kept with all care and fidelity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 16:8
verses.text: For, if any of them shall be found to have been lost through negligence or through any person's dishonesty, thou wilt be involved in the guilt of this, being, in virtue of thy office of Archdeacon, peculiarly responsible for the custody of the said church.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17:1
verses.text: Epistle XXI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17:2
verses.text: To Natalis, Bishop of Salona.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17:3
verses.text: Gregory to Natalis, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17:4
verses.text: We have received at the hands of the deacon Stephen, whom you sent to us, the letters of thy Reverence, wherein you congratulate us on our promotion.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17:5
verses.text: And truly what has been offered in the kindness and earnestness of charity demands full credence, reason having prompted your pontifical order to rejoice with us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17:6
verses.text: We therefore, being cheered by your greeting, declare in conscience that I undertook the burden of dignity with a sick heart.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17:7
verses.text: But, seeing that I could not resist the divine decrees, I have recovered a more cheerful frame of mind.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17:8
verses.text: Wherefore we write to entreat your Reverence that both we and the Christian flock committed to our care may enjoy the succour of your prayers, to the end that in the security of that protection we may have power to overcome the hurricanes of these times.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 17:9
verses.text: The month of February, ninth indiction.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:1
verses.text: Epistle XXV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop of Constantinople, and the Other Patriarchs.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:3
verses.text: Gregory, to John of Constantinople, Eulogius of Alexandria, Gregory of Antioch, John of Jerusalem, and Anastasias, Ex-Patriarch of Antioch.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:4
verses.text: A paribus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:5
verses.text: When I consider how, unworthy as I am, and resisting with my whole soul, I have been compelled to bear the burden of pastoral care, a darkness of sorrow comes over me, and my sad heart sees nothing else but the shadows which allow nothing to be seen.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:6
verses.text: For to what end is a bishop chosen of the Lord but to be an intercessor for the offences of the people? With what confidence, then, can I come as an intercessor for the sins of others to Him before Whom I am not secure about my own? If perchance any one should ask me to become his intercessor with a great man who was incensed against him, and to myself unknown, I should at once reply, I cannot go to intercede for you, having no knowledge of that man from familiar acquaintance with him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:7
verses.text: If then, as man with man, I should properly blush to become an intercessor with one on whom I had no claim, how great is the audacity of my obtaining the place of intercessor for the people with God, whose friendship I am not assured of through the merit of my life! And in this matter I find a still more serious cause of alarm, since we all know well that, when one who is in disfavour is sent to intercede with an incensed person, the mind of the latter is provoked to still greater severity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:8
verses.text: And I am greatly afraid lest the community of believers, whose offences the Lord has so far indulgently borne with, should perish through the addition of my guilt to theirs.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:9
verses.text: But, when in one way or another I suppress this fear, and with mind consoled give myself to the care of my pontifical office, I am deterred by consideration of the immensity of this very task.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:10
verses.text: "For indeed I consider with myself what watchful care is needed that a ruler may be pure in thought, chief in action, discreet in keeping silence, profitable in speech, a near neighbour to every one in sympathy, exalted above all in contemplation, a companion of good livers through humility, unbending against the vices of evil-doers through zeal for righteousness".

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:11
verses.text: All which things when I try to search out with subtle investigation, the very wideness of the consideration cramps me in the particulars.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:12
verses.text: For, as I have already said, there is need of the greatest care that "the ruler be pure in thought, &c".

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:13
verses.text: [A long passage, thus beginning, and ending with  "beyond the limit of order," is found also in Regula Pastoralis, Pt.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:48
verses.text: He orders it well who knows how both through it to tower above sins, and with it to set himself on an equality with other men.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:49
verses.text: Moreover, the virtue of humility ought to be so maintained that the rights of government be not relaxed; lest, when any prelate has lowered himself more than is becoming, he be unable to restrain the life of his subordinates under the bond of discipline; and the severity of discipline is to be so maintained that gentleness be not wholly lost through the over-kindling of zeal.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:50
verses.text: For often vices shew themselves off as virtues, so that niggardliness would fain appear as frugality, extravagance as liberality, cruelty as righteous zeal, laxity as loving-kindness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:51
verses.text: Wherefore both discipline and mercy are far from what they should be, if one be maintained without the other.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:52
verses.text: But there ought to be kept up with great skill of discernment both mercy justly considerate, and discipline smiting kindly.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:61
verses.text: ]  Thus, having undertaken the burden of pastoral care, when I consider all these things and many others of like kind, I seem to be what I cannot be, especially as in this place whosoever is called a Pastor is onerously occupied by external cares; so that it often becomes uncertain whether he exercises the function of a pastor or of an earthly noble.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:62
verses.text: And indeed whosoever is set over his brethren to rule them cannot be entirely free from external cares; and yet there is need of exceeding care lest he be pressed down by them too much.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:63
verses.text: "Whence it is rightly said to Ezekiel, The priests shall not shave their heads, &c".

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:64
verses.text: [See Reg.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:65
verses.text: Past.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:66
verses.text: , Pt.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:67
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:68
verses.text: , ch.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:69
verses.text: 7, to the end.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:70
verses.text: ]  But in this place I see that no such discreet management is possible, since cases of such importance hang over me daily as to overwhelm the mind, while they kill the bodily life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:71
verses.text: Wherefore, most holy brother, I beseech thee by the Judge who is to come, by the assembly of many thousand angels, by the Church of the firstborn who are written in heaven, help me, who am growing weary under this burden of pastoral care, with the intercession of thy prayer, lest its weight oppress me beyond my strength.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:72
verses.text: But, being mindful of what is written, Pray for one another, that ye may be healed (James v.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:73
verses.text: 16), I give also what I ask for.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:74
verses.text: But I shall receive what I give.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:75
verses.text: For, while we are joined to you through the aid of prayer, we hold as it were each other by the hand while walking through slippery places, and it comes to pass, through a great provision of charity, that the foot of each is the more firmly planted in that one leans upon the other.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:76
verses.text: Besides, since with the heart man believeth unto righteousness, and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation, I confess that I receive and revere, as the four books of the Gospel so also the four Councils: to wit, the Nicene, in which the perverse doctrine of Arius is overthrown; the Constantinopolitan also, in which the error of Eunomius and Macedonius is refuted; further, the first Ephesine, in which the impiety of Nestorius is condemned; and the Chalcedonian, in which the pravity of Eutyches and Dioscorus  is reprobated.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:77
verses.text: These with full devotion I embrace, and adhere to with most entire approval; since on them, as on a four-square stone, rises the structure of the holy faith; and whosoever, of whatever life and behaviour he may be, holds not fast to their solidity, even though he is seen to be a stone, yet he lies outside the building.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:78
verses.text: The fifth council also I equally venerate, in which the epistle which is called that of Ibas, full of error, is reprobated; Theodorus, who divides the Mediator between God and men into two subsistences, is convicted of having fallen into the perfidy of impiety; and the writings of Theodoritus, in which the faith of the blessed Cyril is impugned, are refuted as having been published with the daring of madness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:79
verses.text: But all persons whom the aforesaid venerable Councils repudiate I repudiate; those whom they venerate I embrace; since, they having been constituted by universal consent, he overthrows not them but himself, whosoever presumes either to loose those whom they bind, or to bind those whom they loose.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:80
verses.text: Whosoever, therefore, thinks otherwise, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 18:81
verses.text: But whosoever holds the faith of the aforesaid synods, peace be to him from God the Father, through Jesus Christ His Son, Who lives and reigns consubstantially God with Him in the Unity of the Holy Spirit for ever and everi, Amen.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:1
verses.text: Epistle XXVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:2
verses.text: To Anastasius, Patriarch of Antioch.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:3
verses.text: [The beginning of this epistle is the same as that of Epistle VII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:4
verses.text: to the same Anastasius as far as the words "stand on the shore of virtue"; after which it is continued as follows.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:5
verses.text: ]  But, as to your calling me the mouth and lantern of the Lord, and alleging that I profit many by speaking, and am able to give light to many, I confess that you have brought me into a state of the greatest doubt in my estimate of myself.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:6
verses.text: For I consider what I am, and detect in myself no sign of all this good.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:7
verses.text: But I consider also what you are, and I do not think that you can lie.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:8
verses.text: When, then, I would believe what you say, my infirmity contradicts me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:9
verses.text: When I would dispute what is said in my praise, your sanctity contradicts me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:10
verses.text: But I pray you, holy man, let us come to some agreement in this our contest, that, though it is not as you say, it may be so because you say it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:11
verses.text: Moreover, I have addressed my synodical epistle to you, as to the other patriarchs, your brethren; inasmuch as with me you are always what it has been granted you to be by the gift of Almighty God, without regard to what you are accounted not to be by the will of men.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:12
verses.text: I have given some instructions to Boniface the guardian (defensori), who is the bearer of these presents, for him to communicate to your holiness in private.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 19:13
verses.text: Moreover, I have sent you keys of the blessed apostle Peter, who loves you, which are wont to shine forth with many miracles when placed on the bodies of sick persons.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:1
verses.text: Epistle XXVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:2
verses.text: To Anastasius, Archbishop of Corinth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:3
verses.text: Gregory to Anastasius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:4
verses.text: In proportion as the judgments of God are unsearchable ought they to be an object of fear to human apprehension; so that mortal reason, being unable to comprehend them, may of necessity bow under them the neck of a humble heart, to the end that it may follow with the mind's obedient steps where the will of the Ruler may lead.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:5
verses.text: I, then, considering that my infirmity cannot reach to the height of the apostolic See, had rather have declined this burden, lest, having pastoral rule, I should succumb in action through inadequate administration.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:6
verses.text: But, since it is not for us to go against the will of the Lord who disposes all, I obediently followed the way in which it pleased the merciful hand of the Ruler to deal with me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:7
verses.text: For it was necessary that your Fraternity should be informed, even though the present opportunity had not occurred, how the Lord had vouchsafed that I, however unworthy, should preside over the apostolic See.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:8
verses.text: Since, then, reason required this to be done, and an opportunity having occurred through our sending to you the bearer of these presents, that is, Boniface the guardian (defensorem), we are careful not only to offer to your Fraternity by letter the good wishes of charity, but also to inform you of our ordination, as we believe you would wish us to do.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:9
verses.text: Wherefore let your Charity, by a letter in reply, cause us to rejoice for the unity of the Church and the acceptable news of your own welfare; to the end that our bodily absence from each other, which distance of place causes us to endure, may become as presence through interchange of letters.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 20:10
verses.text: We exhort you, also, since we have despatched the above-mentioned  bearer of these presents on certain necessary business to the feet of the most clement prince, and since the mutability of the time is wont to generate many hindrances on the way, that your priestly affection would bestow upon him whatever may be necessary either in provision for his journey by land or in procuring for him the means of navigation, that through God's mercy, he may be able the more quickly to accomplish his intended journey.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 21

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 21:1
verses.text: Epistle XXVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 21:2
verses.text: To Sebastian, Bishop of Rhisinum [in Dalmatia].

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 21:3
verses.text: Gregory to Sebastian, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 21:4
verses.text: Although I deserved to receive no letters from your Blessedness, yet I also do not forget my own forgetfulness; I blame my negligence, I stir up my sluggishness with goads of love, that one who will not pay what he owes of his own accord, may learn even under blows to render it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 21:5
verses.text: Furthermore, I inform you that I have prepared a full representation, with urgent prayers to our most pious lords, to the effect that they ought to have sent the most blessed Lord patriarch Anastasius, with the use of the pallium granted him, to the threshold of the blessed Peter, prince of the apostles, to celebrate with me the solemnities of Mass; to the end that, though he were not allowed to return to his See, he might at least live with me, retaining his dignity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 21:6
verses.text: But of the reason that has arisen for keeping back what I had thus written the bearer of these presents will inform you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 21:7
verses.text: Nevertheless, ascertain the mind of the said lord Anastasius, and inform me in your letters of whatever he may wish to be done in this business.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 22

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 22:1
verses.text: Epistle XXIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 22:2
verses.text: To Aristobulus, Ex-Prefect and Antigraphus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 22:3
verses.text: Gregory to Aristobulus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 22:4
verses.text: For fully expressing my affection I confess that my tongue suffices not: but your own affection will better tell you all that I feel towards you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 22:5
verses.text: I have heard that you are suffering from certain oppositions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 22:6
verses.text: But I am not greatly grieved for this, since it is often the case that a ship which might have reached the depths of the ocean had the breeze been favourable is driven back by an opposing wind at the very beginning of its voyage, but by being driven back is recalled into port.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 22:7
verses.text: Furthermore, if you should by any chance receive for interpretation a lengthy letter of mine, translate it, I pray you, not word for word, but so as to give the sense; since usually, when close rendering of the words is attended to, the force of the ideas is lost.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:2
verses.text: To Romanus, Patrician, and Exarch of Italy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:3
verses.text: Gregory to Romanus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:4
verses.text: Even though there were no immediate cause for writing to your Excellency, yet we ought to shew solicitude for your health and safety so as to learn through frequent intercommunication what we desire to hear about you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:5
verses.text: Besides, it has come to our knowledge that Blandus, bishop of the city of Hortanum, has been detained now for a long time by your Excellency in the city of Ravenna.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:6
verses.text: And the result is that the Church decays, being without a ruler, and the people as being without a shepherd; and infants there, for their sins, die without baptism.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:7
verses.text: And again, since we do not believe that your Excellency has detained him except on the ground of some probable transgression, it is proper that a synod should be held to bring to light any crime that is charged against him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:8
verses.text: And, if such fault is found in him as to lead to his degradation from the priesthood, it is necessary that we should look out for another to be ordained, lest the Church of God should remain untended, and destitute in what the Christian religion does not allow it to be without.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:9
verses.text: But, if your Excellency should perceive that the case is otherwise with him than it is said to be, allow him, I pray you, to return to his church, that he may fulfil his duty to the souls committed to his charge.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 23:10
verses.text: The month of March; the ninth Indiction.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXIV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:2
verses.text: To Venantius, Ex-Monk, Patrician of Syracuse.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:3
verses.text: Gregory to Venantius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:4
verses.text: Many foolish men have supposed that, if I were advanced to the rank of the episcopate, I should decline to address thee, or to keep up communication with thee by letter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:5
verses.text: But this is not so; since I am compelled by the very necessity of my position not to hold my peace.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:6
verses.text: For it is written, Cry aloud, spare not, lift up thy voice like a trumpet (Isai.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:7
verses.text: lviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:8
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:9
verses.text: And again it is written, I have given thee for a watchman unto the house of Israel, thou shalt hear the word at my mouth, and declare it to them from me (Ezek.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:10
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:11
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:12
verses.text: And what follows to the watchman or to the hearer from such declaration being kept back or uttered is forthwith intimated; If, when I say to the wicked, Thou shalt surely die, thou declare it not to him, nor speak to him, that he may turn from his wicked way and live, the wicked man himself shall die in his iniquity; but his blood will I require at thine hand.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:13
verses.text: Yet if thou declare it to the wicked, and he turn not from his iniquity and from his wicked way, he himself indeed shall die in his iniquity, but thou hast delivered thy soul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:14
verses.text: Hence also Paul says to the Ephesians, My hands are pure this day from the blood of all of you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:15
verses.text: For I have not shunned to declare unto you all the counsel of God (Acts xx.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:16
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:17
verses.text: He would not, then, have been pure from the blood of all, had he refused to declare unto them the counsel of God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:18
verses.text: For when the pastor refuses to rebuke those that sin, there is no doubt that in holding his peace he slays them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:19
verses.text: Compelled, therefore, by this consideration, I will speak whether you will or no; for with all my powers I desire either thee to be saved or myself to be rescued from thy death.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:20
verses.text: For thou rememberest in what state of life thou wast, and knowest to what thou hast fallen without regard to the animadversion of supernal strictness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:21
verses.text: Consider, then, thy fault while there is time; dread, while thou canst, the severity of the future judge; lest thou then find it bitter, having shed no tears to avoid it now.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:22
verses.text: Consider what is written; Pray that your flight be not in the winter, neither on the Sabbath day (Matth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:23
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:24
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:25
verses.text: For the numbness of cold impedes walking in the winter, and, according to the ordinance of the law, it is not lawful to walk on the Sabbath day.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:26
verses.text: He, then, attempts to fly in the winter or on the Sabbath day, who then wishes to fly from the wrath of the strict Judge when it is no longer allowed him to walk.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:27
verses.text: Wherefore, while there is time, while it is allowed, fly thou from the animadversion which is of so great dreadfulness: consider what is written; Whatsoever thine hand findeth to do, do it with thy might; for there is neither work, nor device, nor wisdom, in the grave whither thou hastenest (Eccles.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:28
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:29
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:30
verses.text: By the witness of the Gospel thou knowest that divine severity accuses us for idle talk, and demands a strict account of an unprofitable word (Matth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:31
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:32
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:33
verses.text: Consider, then, what it will do for perverse doing, if in its judgment it reprobates some for talking.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:34
verses.text: Ananias had vowed money to God (Acts v.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:35
verses.text: 2 seq.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:36
verses.text: ), which, afterwards, overcome by diabolical persuasion, he withheld.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:37
verses.text: But by what death he was  mulcted thou knowest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:38
verses.text: If then he was deserving of the penalty of death who withdrew the money which he had given to God, consider of how great penalty thou wilt be deserving in the divine judgment, who hast withdrawn, not money, but thyself, from Almighty God, to whom thou hadst devoted thyself in the monastic state of life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:39
verses.text: Wherefore, if thou wilt hear the words of my rebuke so as to follow them, thou wilt come to know in the end how kind and sweet they are.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:40
verses.text: Lo, I confess it, I speak mourning and constrained by sorrow for what thou hast done.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:41
verses.text: I scarce can utter words; and yet thy mind, conscious of guilt, is hardly able to bear what it hears, blushes, is confounded, remonstrates.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:42
verses.text: If, then, it cannot bear the words of dust, what will it do at the judgment of the Creator? And yet I acknowledge the exceeding mercy of heavenly grace, in that it beholds thee flying from life, and nevertheless still reserves thee for life; that it sees thee acting proudly, and still bears with thee; that through its unworthy servants it administers to thee words of rebuke and admonition.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:43
verses.text: So great a thing is this that thou oughtest anxiously to ponder on what Paul says; We exhort you, brethren that ye receive not the grace of God in vain: for he saith, I have heard thee in a time accepted, and in the day of salvation have I succoured thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:44
verses.text: Behold now is the acceptable time, behold now is the day of salvation (2 Cor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:45
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:46
verses.text: 1 seq.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:47
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:48
verses.text: But I know that, when my letter is received, forthwith friends come about thee, thy literary clients are called in, and advice about the purpose of life is sought from the promoters of death; who, loving not thee, but what belongs to thee, tell thee nothing but what may please thee at the time.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:49
verses.text: For such, as thou thyself rememberest, were those thy former counsellors, who drew thee on to the perpetration of so great a sin.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:50
verses.text: To quote to thee something from a secular author, "All things should be considered with friends, but the friends themselves should be considered first".

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:51
verses.text: But, if in thy case thou seekest an adviser, take me, I pray thee, as thy adviser.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:52
verses.text: For no one can be more to be relied on for advice than one who loves not what is thine, but thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:53
verses.text: May Almighty God make known to thy heart with what love and with what charity my heart embraces thee, though so far only as not to offend against divine grace.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:54
verses.text: For I so attack thy fault as to love thy person; I so love thy person as not to embrace the viciousness of thy fault.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:55
verses.text: If, therefore, thou believest that I love thee, approach the threshold of the apostles, and use me as an adviser.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:56
verses.text: But if perchance I am supposed to be too keen in the cause of God, and am suspected for the ardour of my zeal, I will call the whole Church together into counsel on this question, and whatever all are of opinion should be done for good, this I will in no wise contradict, but gladly fulfil and subscribe to what is decided in common.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 24:57
verses.text: May Divine grace keep thee while accomplishing what I have warned thee to do.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 25

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 25:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 25:2
verses.text: To Peter, Bishop of Terracina.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 25:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 25:4
verses.text: Joseph, a Jew, the bearer of these presents, has informed us that, the Jews dwelling in the camp of Terracina having been accustomed to assemble in a certain place for celebrating their festivities, thy Fraternity had expelled them thence, and that they had migrated, and this with thy knowledge and consent, to another place for in like manner observing their festivities; and now they complain that they have been expelled anew from this same place.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 25:5
