verses.text: But, if it is so, we desire thy Fraternity to abstain from giving cause of complaint of this kind, and that they be allowed, as has been the custom, to assemble in the place which, as we have already said, they had obtained with thy knowledge for their place of meeting.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 25:6
verses.text: For those who dissent from the Christian religion must needs be gathered together to unity of faith by gentleness, kindness, admonition, persuasion, lest those whom the sweetness of preaching and the anticipated terror of future judgment might have invited to believe should be repelled by threats and terrors.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 25:7
verses.text: It is right, then, that they should come together kindly to hear the word of God from you rather than that they should become afraid of overstrained austerity.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:2
verses.text: To Peter the Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:3
verses.text: Gregory, bishop, servant of the servants of God, to Peter the Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:4
verses.text: The code of instructions which I gave thee on thy going to Sicily must be diligently perused, so that the greatest care may be taken concerning bishops, lest they mix themselves up in secular causes, except so far as the necessity of defending the poor compels them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:5
verses.text: But what is inserted in the same code concerning monks or clerics ought, I think, in no respect to be varied from.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:6
verses.text: But let thy  Experience observe these things with such great attention as may fulfil my desire in this regard.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:7
verses.text: Further, it has come to my ears that from the times of Antoninus, the defensor, till now, during these last ten years, many persons have endured certain acts of violence from the Roman Church, so that some publicly complain of their boundaries having been violently invaded, their slaves abstracted, and their moveables carried off by force, and not by any judicial process.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:8
verses.text: In all such cases I desire thy Experience to keep intent watch, and whatsoever during these last ten years may be found to have been taken away by violence, or retained unjustly in the name of the Church, to restore it by authority of this my order to him to whom it is found to belong; lest he who has suffered violence should be obliged to come to me, and undertake the labour of so long a journey, in which case it could not be ascertained here before me whether or not he spoke the truth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:9
verses.text: Having regard, then, to the majesty of the Judge who is to come, restore all things that have been sinfully taken away, knowing that thou bringest great gain to me, if thou gatherest [heavenly] reward rather than riches.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:10
verses.text: But we have ascertained that what the greater part complain of is the loss of their slaves, saying that, if any man's bondman, peradventure running away from his master, has declared himself to belong to the Church, the rectors of the Church have at once kept him as a bondman belonging to the Church, without any trial of the case, but supporting with a high hand the word of the bondman.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:11
verses.text: This displeases me as much as it is abhorrent from the judgment of truth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:12
verses.text: Wherefore I desire thy Experience to correct without delay whatever may be found to have been so done: and it is also fit that any such slaves as are now kept in ecclesiastical possession, as they were taken away without trial, should be restored before trial; so that, if holy Church has any legitimate claim to them, their possessors may then be dispossessed by regular process of law.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:13
verses.text: Correct all these things irretractably, since thou wilt be truly a soldier of the blessed apostle Peter if in his causes thou keep guard over the truth, even without his receiving anything.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:14
verses.text: But, if thou seest anything that may justly be claimed as belonging to the Church, beware lest thou ever try to assert such claim by force; especially as I have established a decree under pain of anathema, that tituli may not ever be put by our Church on any urban or rural farm; but whatever may in reason be claimed for the poor ought also to be defended by reason; lest, a good thing being done in a manner that is not good, we be convicted of injustice before Almighty God even in what we justly seek.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:15
verses.text: Moreover, I pray thee, let noble laymen, and the glorious [Praetor] love thee for thy humility, not dread thee for thy pride.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:16
verses.text: And yet, if by any chance thou knowest them to be doing any injustice to the indigent, turn thy humility at once into exaltation, so as to be always submissive to them when they do well, and opposed to them when they do ill.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:17
verses.text: But so behave that neither thy humility be remiss nor thy authority stiff, to the end that uprightness season humility, and humility render thy very uprightness gentle.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:18
verses.text: Further, since it has been customary for bishops to assemble here for the anniversary of the pontiff, forbid their coming for the day of my ordination, since foolish and vain superfluity delights me not.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:19
verses.text: But if they must needs assemble, let them come for the anniversary of Peter, the prince of the apostles, to render thanks to him by whose bounty they are pastors.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:20
verses.text: Farewell.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 26:21
verses.text: Given this XVII day of the Kalends of April, in the ninth year of the Emperor Mauricius.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 27

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 27:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 27:2
verses.text: To Anthemius, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 27:3
verses.text: Gregory to Anthemius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 27:4
verses.text: We charged thee on thy departure, and remember to have afterwards enjoined on thee by letter, to take care of the poor, and, if thou shouldest find any in those parts to be in want, to inform me by letter: and thou hast been at pains to do this with regard to very few.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 27:5
verses.text: Now, I desire that, as soon as thou hast received this present order, thou offer to Pateria, my father's sister, forty solidi for shoe-money for her boys, and four hundred modii of wheat; to the lady Palatina, the widow of Urbicus, twenty solidi and three hundred modii of wheat; to the lady Viviana, widow of Felix, twenty solidi and three hundred modii of wheat.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 27:6
verses.text: And let all these eighty solidi be charged together in thy accounts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 27:7
verses.text: But bring hither with speed the sum of thy receipts, and be here, with the Lord's help, by Easter Day.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 28

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 28:1
verses.text: Epistle XLI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 28:2
verses.text: To Peter, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 28:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 28:4
verses.text: The venerable Paulinus bishop of the city of Taurum (Taurianum in Brutia), has told us that his monks have been scattered by reason of barbaric invasions, and that they are now wandering through the whole of Sicily, and that, being without a ruler, they neither have a care of their souls, nor pay attention to the discipline of their profession.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 28:5
verses.text: On this account we enjoin thee to search out with all care and diligence, and collect together, these same monks, and to place them with the said bishop, their ruler, in the monastery of Saint Theodorus situate in the city of Messana, that both such as are there now, whom we find to be in need of a ruler, and those of his congregation whom you may have found and brought back, may be able, under his leadership, to serve the Almighty Lord together.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 28:6
verses.text: Know also that we have signified this matter to the venerable Felix, bishop of the same city, lest anything ordained in the diocese committed to him should be disturbed without his knowledge.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:1
verses.text: Epistle XLII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:2
verses.text: To Anthemius, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:3
verses.text: Gregory to Anthemius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:4
verses.text: John, our brother and fellow-bishop, in a schedule sent to us by his cleric Justus, has among many other things intimated to us as follows: that some monks of the diocese of Surrentum transmigrate from monastery to monastery as they please, and depart from the rule of their own abbot out of desire for a worldly life; nay even (what is known to be unlawful) that they aim severally at having property of their own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:5
verses.text: Wherefore we command thy Experience by this present order, that no monk be henceforth allowed to migrate from monastery to monastery, and that thou permit not any one of them to have anything of his own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:6
verses.text: But, if any one whatever should so presume, let him be sent back with adequate constraint to the monastery in which he lived at first, to be under the rule of his own abbot from which he had escaped; lest, if we allow so great an iniquity to take its course uncorrected, the souls of those that are lost be required from the souls of their superiors.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:7
verses.text: Further, if any of the clergy should chance to become monks, let it not be lawful for them to return anew to the same church in which they had formerly served, or to any other; unless one should be a monk of such a life that the bishop under whom he had formerly served should think him worthy of the priesthood, so that he may be chosen by him, and by him ordained to such place as he may think fit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:8
verses.text: And since we have learnt that some among the monks have plunged into such great wickedness as publicly to take to themselves wives, do thou seek them out with all vigilance, and, when found, send them back with due constraint to the monasteries of which they had been monks.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:9
verses.text: But neglect not to deal also with the clergy who profess monasticism, as we have said above.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 29:10
verses.text: For so thou wilt be pleasing in the eyes of God, and be found partaker of a full reward.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:1
verses.text: Epistle XLIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:2
verses.text: To Leander Bishop of Hispalis (Seville).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:3
verses.text: Gregory to Leander, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:4
verses.text: I should have wished to reply to your letters with full application of mind, were I not so worn by the labour of my pastoral charge as to be more inclined to weep than to say anything.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:5
verses.text: And this your Reverence will take care to understand and allow for in the very text of my letters, when I speak negligently to one whom I exceedingly love.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:6
verses.text: For, indeed, I am in this place tossed by such billows of this world that I am in no wise able to steer into port the old and rotten ship of which, in the hidden dispensation of God, I have assumed the guidance.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:7
verses.text: Now in front the billows rush in, now at the side heaps of foamy sea swell up, now from behind the storm follows on.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:8
verses.text: And, disquieted in the midst of all this, I am compelled sometimes to steer in the very face of the opposing waters; sometimes, turning the ship aside, to avoid the threats of the billows slantwise.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:9
verses.text: I groan, because I feel that through my negligence the bilgewater of vices increases, and, as the storm meets the vessel violently, the rotten planks already sound of shipwreck.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:10
verses.text: With tears I remember how I have lost the placid shore of my rest, and with sighs I behold the land which still, with the winds of affairs blowing against me, I cannot reach.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:11
verses.text: If, then, thou lovest me, dearest brother, stretch out to me in the midst of these billows the hand of thy prayer; that from helping me in my labours thou mayest, in very return for the benefit, be the stronger in thine own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:12
verses.text: I cannot, however, at all fully express in words my joy on having learnt that our common son, the most glorious King Rechared, has been converted with most entire devotion to the Catholic faith.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:13
verses.text: In describing his character to me in thy letters thou hast made me love him, though I know him not.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:14
verses.text: But, since you know the wiles of the ancient foe, how against conquerors he prepares all the fiercer war, let your Holiness keep watch the more warily over him, that he may accomplish what he has well begun, nor lift himself up for good works accomplished; that he may keep the faith which he has come to know by the merits also of his life, and shew by his works that he is a citizen of the eternal kingdom, to the end that after a course of many years he may pass from kingdom to kingdom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:15
verses.text: But with respect to trine immersion in baptism, no truer answer can be given than what you have yourself felt to be right; namely that, where there is one faith, a diversity of usage does no harm to holy Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:16
verses.text: Now we, in immersing thrice, signify the sacraments of the three days' sepulture; so that, when the infant is a third time lifted out of the water, the resurrection after a space of three days may be expressed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:17
verses.text: Or, if any one should perhaps think that this is done out of veneration for the supreme Trinity, neither so is there any objection to immersing the person to be baptized in the water once, since, there being one substance in three subsistences, it cannot be in any way reprehensible to immerse the infant in baptism either thrice or once, seeing that by three immersions the Trinity of persons, and in one the singleness of the Divinity may be denoted.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:18
verses.text: But, inasmuch as up to this time it has been the custom of heretics to immerse infants in baptism thrice, I am of opinion that this ought not to be done among you; lest, while they number the immersions, they should divide the Divinity, and while they continue to do as they have been used to do, they should boast of having got the better of our custom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:19
verses.text: Moreover, I send to your to me most sweet Fraternity the volumes of which I have appended a notice below.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:20
verses.text: What I had spoken in exposition of the blessed Job, which you express in your letter your wish to have sent to you, being weak both in sense and language as I had delivered it in homilies, I have tried as I could to change into the form of a treatise, which is in course of being written out by scribes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:21
verses.text: And, were I not crippled by the haste of the bearer of these presents, I should have wished to transmit to you the whole without diminution; especially as I have written this same work for your Reverence, that I may be seen to have sweated in my labours for him whom I love above all others.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:22
verses.text: Besides, if you find time allowed you from ecclesiastical engagements, you already know how it is with me: even though absent in the body, I behold thee always present with me; for I carry the image of thy countenance stamped within the bowels of my heart.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 30:23
verses.text: Given in the month of May.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:1
verses.text: Epistle XLIV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:2
verses.text: To Peter, Subdeacon of Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:4
verses.text: With regard to our having so long delayed sending off thy messenger, we have been so occupied with the engagements of the Paschal festival that we have been unable to let him go sooner.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:5
verses.text: But, with regard to the questions on which thou hast desired instruction, thou wilt learn below how, after fully considering them all, we have determined them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:6
verses.text: We have ascertained that the peasants of the Church are exceedingly aggrieved in respect of the prices of corn, in that the sum appointed them to pay is not kept in due proportion in times of plenty.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:7
verses.text: And it is our will that in all times, whether the crops of corn be more or less abundant, the measure of proportion be according to the market price.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:8
verses.text: It is our will also that corn which is  lost by shipwreck be fully accounted for; but on condition that there be no neglect on thy part in transmitting it; lest, the proper time for transmitting it being allowed to pass by, loss should ensue from your fault.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:9
verses.text: Moreover, we have seen it to be exceedingly wrong and unjust that anything should be received from the peasants of the Church in the way of sextariatics, or that they should be compelled to give a larger modius than is used in the granaries of the Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:10
verses.text: Wherefore we enjoin by this present warning that corn may never be received from the peasants of the Church in modii of more than eighteen sextarii; unless perchance there be anything that the sailors are accustomed to receive over and above, the consumption of which on board ship they themselves attest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:11
verses.text: We have also ascertained that on some estates of the Church a most unjust exaction is practised, in that three and a half [modii] in seventy are demanded by the farmers;a thing shameful to be spoken of.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:12
verses.text: And yet even this is not enough; but something besides is said to be exacted according to a custom of many years.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:13
verses.text: This practice we altogether detest, and desire it to be utterly extirpated from the patrimony.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:14
verses.text: But, whether in this or in other minute imposts, let thy Experience consider what is paid too much per pound, and what is in any way unfairly received from the peasants; and reduce all to a fixed payment, and, so far as the powers of the peasants go, let them make a payment in gross amounting to seventy-two: and let neither grains beyond the pound, nor an excessive pound, nor any further imposts beyond the pound, be exacted; but, through thy valuation, according as there is ability to pay, let the payment be made up to a certain sum, that so there may be in no wise any shameful exaction.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:15
verses.text: But, lest after my death these very imposts, which we have disallowed as extras but allowed in augmentation of the regular payments, should again in any way be put on additionally, and so the sum of the payment should be found to be increased and the peasants be compelled to pay additional charges over and above what is due, we desire thee to draw up charters of security, to be signed by thee, declaring that each person is to pay such an amount, to the exclusion of grains (siliquae), imposts, or granary dues.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:16
verses.text: Moreover, whatever out of these several items used to accrue to the rector [sc.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:17
verses.text: patrimonii], we will that by virtue of this present order it shall accrue to thee out of the total sum paid.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:18
verses.text: Before all things we desire thee carefully to attend to this; that no unjust weights be used in exacting payments.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:19
verses.text: If thou shouldest find any, break them and cause true ones to be made.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:20
verses.text: For my son the servant of God, Diaconus, has already found such as displeased him; but he had not liberty to change them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:21
verses.text: We will, then, that, saving excepted cibaria of small value, nothing else beyond the just weights be exacted from the husbandmen of the Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:22
verses.text: Further, we have ascertained that the first charge of burdatio exceedingly cripples our peasants, in that before they can sell the produce of their labour they are compelled to pay taxes; and, not having of their own to pay with, they borrow from public pawnbrokers, and pay a heavy consideration for the accommodation; whence it results that they are crippled by heavy expenses.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:23
verses.text: Wherefore we enjoin by this present admonition that thy  Experience advance to them from the public fund all that they might have borrowed from strangers, and that it be repaid by the peasants of the Church by degrees as they may have wherewith to pay, lest, while for a time in narrow circumstances, they should sell at too cheap a rate what might afterwards have sufficed for the payment of the due, and even so not have enough.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:24
verses.text: It has come to our knowledge also that immoderate fees are received on the marriages of peasants: concerning which we order that no marriage fees shall exceed the sum of one solidus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:25
verses.text: If any are poor, they should give even less; but if any are rich, let them by no means exceed the aforesaid sum of a solidus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:26
verses.text: And we desire no part of these marriage fees to be credited to our account, but that they should go to the benefit of the farmer (conductorem).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:27
verses.text: We have also ascertained that when some farmers die their relatives are not allowed to succeed them, but that their goods are withdrawn to the uses of the Church: with regard to which thing we decree that the relatives of the deceased who live on the property of the Church shall succeed them as their heirs, and that nothing shall be withdrawn from the substance of the deceased.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:28
verses.text: But, if any one should leave young children, let discreet persons be chosen to take charge of their parents' goods, till they come to such an age as to be able to manage their own property.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:29
verses.text: We have ascertained also that, if any one of a family has committed a fault, he is required to make amends, not in his own person, but in his substance: concerning which practice we order that, whosoever has committed a fault, he shall be punished in his own person as he deserves.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:30
verses.text: Moreover, let no present (commodum) be received from him, unless perchance it be some trifle which may go to the profit of the officer who may have been sent to him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:31
verses.text: We have ascertained also that, as often as a farmer has taken away anything unjustly from his husbandman, it is indeed required from the farmer, but not restored to him from whom it was taken: concerning which thing we order that whatever may have been taken away by violence from any one of a family be restored to him from whom it was taken away, and not accrue to our profit, lest we ourselves should seem to be abettors of violence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:32
verses.text: Furthermore, we will that, if thy Experience should at any time despatch those who are under thy command in causes that arise beyond the limits of the patrimony, they may indeed receive small gratuities from those to whom they are sent; yet so that they themselves may have the advantage of them: for we would not have the treasury of the Church defiled by base gains.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:33
verses.text: We also command thy Experience to see to this: that farmers never be appointed on the estates of the Church for a consideration (commodum); lest, a consideration being looked for, the farmers should be frequently changed; of which changing what else is the result but that the Church farms are never cultivated? But lest also the leases [i-e: by the Church to the farmers] be adjusted according to the sum of the payments due.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:34
verses.text: We desire thee to receive no more from the estates of the Church on account of the store-houses and stores beyond what is customary; but let thine own stores which we have ordered to be procured be procured from strangers.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:35
verses.text: It has come to our ears that three pounds of gold have been unjustly taken away from Peter the farmer of Subpatriana; concerning which matter examine closely Fantinus the guardian (defensorem); and, if they have manifestly been unjustly and improperly taken, restore them without any delay.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:36
verses.text: We have also ascertained that the peasants have paid a second time the burdationwhich Theodosius had exacted from them but had failed to pay over, so that they have been taxed twice.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:37
verses.text: This was done because his substance was not sufficient for meeting his debt to the Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:38
verses.text: But, since we are informed through our son, the servant of God Diaconus, that this deficiency can be made good out of his effects, we will that fifty-seven solidi be repaid to the peasants without any abatement, lest they should be found to have been taxed twice over.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:39
verses.text: Moreover, if it is the case that forty solidi of his effects remain over and above what will indemnify the peasants (which sum thou art said also to have in thy hands), we will that they be given to his daughter, to enable her to recover her effects which she had pawned.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:40
verses.text: We desire also her father's goblet (batiolam) to be restored to her.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:41
verses.text: The glorious magister militum Campanianus had left twelve solidi a year out of the Varronian estate to his notary John; and this we order thee to pay every year without any hesitation to the granddaughter of Euplus the farmer, although she may have received all the  chattels of the said Euplus, except perhaps his cash; and we desire thee also to give her out of his cash five-and-twenty solidi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:42
verses.text: A silver saucer is said to have been pawned for one solidus, and a cup for six solidi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:43
verses.text: After interrogating Dominicus the secretary, or others who may know, redeem the pledge, and restore the aforesaid little vessels.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:44
verses.text: We thank thy Solicitude for that, after I had enjoined thee, in the business of my brother, to send him back his money, thou hast so consigned the matter to oblivion as if something had been said to thee by the last of thy slaves.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:45
verses.text: But now let even thy NegligenceI cannot say thy Experiencestudy to get this done; and whatever of his thou mayest find to be in the hands of Antoninus send back to him with all speed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:46
verses.text: In the matter of Salpingus the Jew a letter has been found which we have caused to be forwarded to thee, in order that, after reading it and becoming fully acquainted with his case and that of a certain widow who is said to be implicated in the same business, thou mayest make answer as may appear to thee just concerning the fifty-one solidi which are known to be returnable, so that the creditors may in no way be defrauded unjustly of the debts due to them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:47
verses.text: A moiety of his legacy has been given to Antoninus; a moiety will be redeemed: which moiety we desire to be made up to him out of the common substance; and not to him only, but also to the guardians (defensoribus) and strangers (pergrinis) to whom he [the testator] has left anything under the title of a legacy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:48
verses.text: To the family (familiae) also we desire the legacy to be paid; which, however, is our concern.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:49
verses.text: Having, then, made up the account for our part, that is for three-quarters, make the payment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:50
verses.text: We desire thee to give something out of the money of the Church of Canusium to the clergy of the same Church, to the end that they who now suffer from want may have some sustenance; and that, if it should please God that a bishop should be ordained, he may have a maintenance.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:51
verses.text: As to lapsed priests, or any others of the clergy, we desire thee in dealing with their property to keep free from any contamination.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:52
verses.text: But seek out the poorest regular monasteries which know how to live according to God, and consign the lapsed to penance in these monasteries; and let the property of the lapsed go to the benefit of the place in which they are consigned to penance, to the end that those who have the care of their correction may have aid themselves from their means.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:53
verses.text: But, if they have relations, let their property be given to their legitimate relations; yet so that an allowance for those to whom they have been consigned for penance be sufficiently provided.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:54
verses.text: But, if any of an ecclesiastical community, whether priests, levites, or monks, or clerics, or any others, shall have lapsed, we will that they be consigned to penance, but that the Church shall retain its claim to their property.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:55
verses.text: Yet let them receive for their own use enough to maintain them during their penance, lest, if left destitute, they should be burdensome to the places whereto they have been consigned.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:56
verses.text: If any have relations on the ecclesiastical domain, let their property be delivered to them, that it may be preserved in their hands subject to the Church's claim.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:57
verses.text: Three years ago the subdeacons of all the churches in Sicily, in accordance with the custom of the Roman Church, were forbidden all conjugal intercourse with their wives.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:58
verses.text: But it appears to me hard and improper that one who has not been accustomed to such continency, and has not previously promised chastity, should be compelled to separate himself from his wife, and thereby (which God forbid) fall into what is worse.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:59
verses.text: Hence it seems good to me that from the present day all bishops should be told not to presume to make any one a subdeacon who does not promise to live chastely; that so what was not of set purpose desired in the past may not be forcibly required, but that cautious provision may be made for the future.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:60
verses.text: But those who since the prohibition of three years ago have lived continently with their wives are to be praised and rewarded, and exhorted to continue in their good way.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:61
verses.text: But, as for those who since the prohibition have been unwilling to abstain from intercourse with their wives, we desire them not to be advanced to a sacred order; since no one ought to approach the ministry of the altar but one who has been of approved chastity before undertaking the ministry.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:62
verses.text: For Liberatus the tradesman, who has commended himself to the Church, dwelling on the Cincian estate, we desire thee to make an annual provision; which provision do thou estimate thyself as to what it ought to be, that it may be reported to me and charged in thy accounts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:63
verses.text: With regard to the present indiction I have already got information from our son the servant of God Diaconus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:64
verses.text: One John, a monk, has died and left Fantinus the guardian (defensorem) his heir to the extent of one half.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:65
verses.text: Hand over to the latter what has been left him, but charge him not to presume to do the like again.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:66
verses.text: But appoint what he should receive for his work, so that it be not fruitless to him; and let him remember that one who lives on the pay of the Church should not pant after private gains.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:67
verses.text: But, if anything should accrue to the Church, without sin and without the lust of concupiscence, through those who transact the business of the Church, it is right that these should not be without fruit of their labour.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:68
verses.text: Still let it be reserved for our judgment how they should be remunerated.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:69
verses.text: As to the money of Rusticianus, look thoroughly into the case, and carry out what appears to thee to be just.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:70
verses.text: Admonish the magnificent Alexander to conclude the cause between himself and holy Church; which if he peradventure shall neglect to do, do thou, in the fear of God and with honour preserved, bring this same cause to an issue as thou art able.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:71
verses.text: We desire thee also to expend something in this business; and, if it can be done, let him be spared the cost of what has to be given to others, provided he terminates the cause which he has with us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:72
verses.text: Restore without any delay the donation of the handmaiden of God who has lapsed and been sent into a monastery, to the end that (as I have said above) the same place that bears the toil of attending to her may have provision for her from what she has.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:73
verses.text: But recover also whatever of hers is in the hands of others, and hand it over to the aforesaid monastery.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:74
verses.text: Send to us the payments of Xenodochius of Via Nova to the amount thou hast told us of, since thou hast them by thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:75
verses.text: But give something, according to thy discretion, to the agent whom thou hast deputed in the same patrimony.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:76
verses.text: Concerning the handmaiden of God who was with Theodosius, by name Extranea, it seems to me that thou shouldest give her an allowance, if thou thinkest it advantageous, or at any rate return to her the donation which she made.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:77
verses.text: The house of the monastery which Antoninus had taken from the monastery, giving thirty solidi for it, restore thou without the least delay, the money being repaid.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:78
verses.text: After thoroughly investigating the truth restore the onyx phials, which I send back to thee by the bearer of these presents.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:79
verses.text: If Saturninus is at liberty and not employed with thee, send him to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:80
verses.text: Felix, a farmer under the lady Campana, whom she had left free and ordered to be exempt from examination, said that seventy-two solidi had been taken from him by Maximus the sub-deacon, for paying which he asserted that he sold or pledged all the property that he had in Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:81
verses.text: But the lawyers said that he could not be exempt from examination concerning acts of fraud.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:82
verses.text: However, when he was returning to us from Campania, he perished in a storm.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:83
verses.text: We desire thee to seek out his wife and children, to redeem whatever he had pledged, repay the price of what he had sold, and moreover provide them with some maintenance; seeing that Maximus had sent the man into Sicily and there taken from him what he alleged.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:84
verses.text: Ascertain, therefore, what has been taken from him, and restore it without any delay to his wife and children.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:85
verses.text: Read all these things over carefully, and put aside all that familiar negligence of thine.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:86
verses.text: My writings which I have sent to the peasants cause thou to be read over throughout all the estates, that they may know in what points to defend themselves, under our authority, against acts of wrong; and let either the originals or copies be given them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:87
verses.text: See that thou observe everything without abatement: for, with regard to what I have written to thee for the observance of justice, I am absolved; and, if thou art negligent, thou art guilty.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:88
verses.text: Consider the terrible Judge who is coming: and let thy conscience now anticipate His advent with fear and trembling, lest it should then fear [not?] without cause, when heaven and earth shall tremble before Him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 31:89
verses.text: Thou hast heard what I wish to be done: see that thou do it.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 32

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 32:1
verses.text: Epistle XLVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 32:2
verses.text: To Peter the Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 32:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 32:4
verses.text: The divine precepts admonish us to love our neighbours as ourselves; and, seeing that we are enjoined to love them with this charity, how much more ought we to succour them by supplies to their carnal needs, that we may relieve their distress, if not in all respects, yet at least with some support.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 32:5
verses.text: Inasmuch, then, as we have found that the son of the most worthy Godiscalchus is in distress, not only from loss of sight, but also from want of food, we hold it necessary to provide for him as far as possible.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 32:6
verses.text: Wherefore we enjoin thy Experience by this present order to supply to him for sustaining life twenty-four modii of wheat every year, and also twelve modii of beans and twenty decimatesof wine; which may afterwards be debited in thy accounts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 32:7
verses.text: So act, therefore, that the bearer of these presents may have to complain of no delay in receiving the gifts of the Lord, and that thou mayest be found partaker in the well administered benefit.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:1
verses.text: Epistle XLVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:2
verses.text: To Virgilius, Bishop of Arelate (Arles) and Theodorus, Bishop of Massilia (Marseilles).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:3
verses.text: Gregory to Virgilius, Bishop of Arelate, and Theodorus, Bishop of Massilia, in Gaul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:4
verses.text: Though the opportunity of a suitable time and suitable persons has failed me so far for writing to your Fraternity and duly returning your salutation, the result has been that I can now at one and the same time acquit myself of what is due to love and fraternal relationship, and also touch on the complaint of certain persons which has reached us, with respect to the way in which the souls of the erring should be saved.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:5
verses.text: Very many, though indeed of the Jewish religion, resident in this province, and from time to time travelling for various matters of business to the regions of Massilia, have apprized us, that many of the Jews settled in those parts have been brought to the font of baptism more by force than by preaching.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:6
verses.text: Now, I consider the intention in such cases to be worthy of praise, and allow that it proceeds from the love of our Lord.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:7
verses.text: But I fear lest this same intention, unless adequate enforcement from Holy Scripture accompany it, should either have no profitable result, or even (which God forbid) the loss of the souls which we wish to save should further ensue.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:8
verses.text: For, when any one is brought to the font of baptism, not by the sweetness of preaching, but by compulsion, he returns to his former superstition, and dies the worse from having been born again.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:9
verses.text: Let, therefore, your Fraternity stir up such men by frequent preaching, to the end that through the sweetness of their teacher they may desire the more to change their old life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:10
verses.text: For so our purpose is rightly accomplished, and the mind of the convert returns not again to his former vomit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 33:11
verses.text: Wherefore discourse must be addressed to them, such as may burn up the thorns of error in them, and illuminate what is dark in them by preaching, so that your Fraternity may through your frequent admonition receive a reward for them, and lead them, so far as God may grant it, to the regeneration of a new life.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34:1
verses.text: Epistle XLVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34:2
verses.text: To Theodorus, Duke of Sardinia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34:3
verses.text: Gregory to Theodorus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34:4
verses.text: The justice which you bear in your mind you ought to shew in the light of your deeds.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34:5
verses.text: Now Juliana, abbess of the monastery of Saint Vitus which Vitula of venerable memory had once built, has intimated to us that possession of the aforesaid monastery is claimed by Donatus, your official; who, seeing himself to be fortified by your patronage, scorns to have resort to a judicial examination of the case.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34:6
verses.text: But now let your Glory enjoin this same official, with the aforesaid hand-maiden of God, to submit the matter to arbitration to the end that whatever may be decided as to the question in dispute by the judgment of the arbitrators may be carried into effect; so that, whatever he may find he has to lose or keep, what he does may not be done as a deed of virtue, but set down to the justice of the law.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34:7
verses.text: Further, Pompeiana, a religious lady, who is known to have established a monastery in her own house, has complained that the mother of her deceased son-in-law wishes to annul his will, to the end that her son's last disposition of his property may be made of none effect.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34:8
verses.text: On this account we hold it necessary with paternal charity to exhort your Glory to lend yourself willingly, with due regard to justice, to pious causes, and kindly order that whatever these persons have a rightful claim to be secured to them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 34:9
verses.text: Now, we beseech the Lord to direct the way of your life propitiously, and grant you a prosperous administration of your dignified office.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 35

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 35:1
verses.text: Epistle XLIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 35:2
verses.text: To Honoratus, Deacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 35:3
verses.text: Gregory to Honoratus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 35:4
verses.text: Since we have undertaken, however undeserving, a place of government, it is our duty to succour our brethren in need, so far as our power extends.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 35:5
verses.text: Januarius, then, our brother and fellow-bishop of the metropolitan city of Caralis (Cagliari), has been here in the city of Rome, and informed us that the glorious magister militum, Theodorus, who is known to have received the dukedom of the island of Sardinia, is doing many things there contrary to the commands of our most pious lords, whereby with fitting clemency and gentleness they removed many hardships of proprietors, or of citizens of their empire.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 35:6
verses.text: Wherefore we desire you at a suitable time to represent the case to our most pious lords in accordance with what the provincials of the aforesaid island justly and reasonably demand; seeing that on a previous occasion also their sacred imperial letters were sent to the glorious Magister militum Edancius, who was in the seventh indiction duke of Sardinia, in which they ordered all these present grievances to be redressed, to the end that their commands, proceeding from the bountifulness of their piety, might be observed unshaken by dukes who might come in course of time to be in power, and that the benefit thereof might not be squandered away by administrators; that so a quiet life might be led under the clement empire of our lords, and for the ordinance which with tranquil mind they grant to their subjects they might receive multiplied compensation at the coming of the eternal judge.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:1
verses.text: Epistle L.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:2
verses.text: To Anthemius the Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:3
verses.text: Gregory to Anthemius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:4
verses.text: Even as, through the ordering of God as it hath pleased Him, we have received the place of government, so ought we to be solicitous for the souls committed to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:5
verses.text: Now we find that in the Eumorphian island, in which, as is well known, there is an oratory of the blessed Peter, Prince of the Apostles, a large number of men with their wives from various patrimonies have fled to it for refuge, through stress of barbarian ferocity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:6
verses.text: This we consider inexpedient: for, there being other places of refuge near at hand, why should women have their abode there with monks? Wherefore we enjoin thy Experience by this present order from this time forward to allow no woman, whether she be under ecclesiastical jurisdiction or any other, to take up her abode or tarry there; but let them provide for themselves a place of refuge (there being, as has been said above, so many in the neighbourhood) wherever they may choose; so that all intercourse with women may henceforth be put an end to; lest, if we should desist from taking all the care we can, and guarding against the snares of the enemy, we henceforth (which God forbid) should be culpable in case of anything wrong taking place.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:7
verses.text: Delay not, therefore, to give to the abbot Felix, the bearer of these presents, one thousand five hundred pounds of lead, which he is known to be in want of in the same island, which may be charged afterwards in thy accounts, when the whole quantity shall be known.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:8
verses.text: So proceed, then, that thou mayest provide thyself with some, if any can be profitably used for the buildings of the same island.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:9
verses.text: Moreover, since congregations of monks in the islands are exposed to hardship, we forbid boys under eighteen years of age to be received into these monasteries.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:10
verses.text: Or, if there are any now there, let thy Experience remove them, and send them to the city of Rome.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 36:11
verses.text: We desire thee in all respects to observe this in Palmaria also and the other islands.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:1
verses.text: Epistle LII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:2
verses.text: To Symmachus the Defensor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:3
verses.text: Gregory to Symmachus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:4
verses.text: My son Boniface the deacon has told me that thy Experience had written to say that a monastery built by Labina, a religious lady, is now ready for monks to be settled in it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:5
verses.text: And indeed I praised thy solicitude; but we wish that some other place than that which has been assigned for the purpose should be provided; but with the condition, in view of the insecurity of the time, that one above the sea be looked out for, which is either fortified by its position, or at all events can be fortified without much labour.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:6
verses.text: So may we send monks thither, to the end that the island itself, hitherto without a monastery, may be improved by having this way of life upon it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:7
verses.text: For carrying out and providing for this business we have given directions to Horosius, the bearer of this present order, with whom thy Experience must go round the  shores of Corsica, and if any more suitable place in the possession of any private person should be found, we are prepared to give a suitable price, that we may be able to make some secure arrangement.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:8
verses.text: We have enjoined the aforesaid Horosius to proceed to the island Gorgonia; and let thy Experience accompany him, and do you so avenge the evils that we have ascertained to have found entrance there that through the punishment you shall inflict the aforesaid island may remain corrected for the future also.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:9
verses.text: Let the same abbot Horosius set in order the monasteries of this island, and so hasten to return to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:10
verses.text: Let, then, thy Experience so act that in both these matters, that is, both in providing for monasteries in Corsica, and in correcting the monks of Gorgonia, thou mayest make haste to obey, not our will, but that of Almighty God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:11
verses.text: Moreover we desire that the priests who abide in Corsica shall be forbidden to have any intercourse with women, except it may be a mother, or a sister, or a wife, towards whom chastity should be observed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:12
verses.text: But to the three persons about whom thy Experience has written to my son the aforesaid deacon Boniface, give whatsoever thou deemest sufficient for them, since they are in grievous need; and this we will allow thee afterwards in thy accounts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 37:13
verses.text: Given in the month of July.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 38

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 38:1
verses.text: Epistle LVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 38:2
verses.text: To Peter, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 38:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 38:4
verses.text: Being exceedingly desirous of observing the festivals of saints, we have thought it needful to address this our letter of direction to thy Experience, informing thee that we have arranged for the dedication with all solemnity, with the help of the Lord, in the month of August, of the Oratory of the Blessed Mary lately built in the cell of brethren where the abbot Marinianus is known to preside, to the end that what we have begun may through the Lord's operation be completed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 38:5
verses.text: But, inasmuch as the poverty of that cell requires that we should assist in that day of festival, we therefore desire thee to give for celebrating the dedication, to be distributed to the poor, ten solidi in gold, thirty amphorae of wine, two hundred lambs, two orcae of oil, twelve wethers, and a hundred hens, which may be afterwards charged in thy accounts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 38:6
verses.text: Provide therefore for this being done at once without any delay, that our desires, God granting it, may take speedy effect.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 39

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 39:1
verses.text: Epistle LVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 39:2
verses.text: To Severus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 39:3
verses.text: Gregory to Severus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 39:4
verses.text: We learn from thy Fraternity's epistle that, with regard to the choice of a bishop, some are agreed in favour of Ocleatinus, with whom, since we disallow him, they need not further concern themselves.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 39:5
verses.text: But give notice to the inhabitants of that city that, if they should find any one in their own Church fit for that work, they all transfer their choice to him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 39:6
verses.text: Otherwise the bearer of these presents will point out a person, of whom I have told him, in favour of whom the notification of the election should be made.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 39:7
verses.text: Do you, moreover, be prudent and careful with regard to your visitation of the same Church, that its property may be preserved inviolate, and its interests attended to after the accustomed manner under your management.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 40

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 40:1
verses.text: Epistle LVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 40:2
verses.text: To Arsicinus Duke, the Clergy, Nobility, and Common People (ordini et plebi) of the City of Ariminum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 40:3
verses.text: Gregory to Arsicinus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 40:4
verses.text: How ready is the devotion of your love in expectation of a pontiff the text of the report which you have addressed to us shews.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 40:5
verses.text: But, since the ordainer ought in such cases to be exceedingly careful, we are watching over this case with due deliberation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 40:6
verses.text: And so we warn your Charity by this present writing that no  one need trouble himself to apply to us in favour of Ocleatinus: but, if any one is found in your own city to undertake this work with profit, so that he cannot be objected to by us, let your choice concur in his favour.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 40:7
verses.text: But, if no one should be found fit for it, we have mentioned to the bearers of these presents one to whom you may no less accord your consent.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 40:8
verses.text: But do you with one accord pray faithfully, that, whosoever may be ordained, he may be able both to be profitable to you and to display priestly service worthy of our God.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 41

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 41:1
verses.text: Epistle LXI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 41:2
verses.text: To Gennadius, Patrician and Exarch of Africa.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 41:3
verses.text: Gregory to Gennadius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 41:4
verses.text: That you have unceasingly the fear of God before your eyes, and pursue justice, the subdued necks of enemies testify; but, that the grace of Christ may keep your Glory in the same prosperity, restrain, as you have been wont, with speedy prohibition whatever things you discover to be committed wrongfully, so that, fortified with the arms of justice, you may overcome hostile attacks with the power of faith, which is the top of all virtue.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 41:5
verses.text: Now Marinianus, our brother and fellow-bishop of the city of Turris has tearfully represented to us that the poor of his city are being vexed everywhere, and afflicted by expenses in the way of gifts or payments; and further that the religious of his church endure serious molestation from the men of Theodorus the magister militum, and suffer bodily injuries; and that this thing is breaking out to such a pitch that (shocking to say) they are thrust into prison, and that he himself also is seriously hindered by the aforesaid glorious person in causes pertaining to his Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 41:6
verses.text: How opposed such things are, if indeed they are true, to the discipline of the republic you yourselves know.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 41:7
verses.text: And, since it befits your Excellency to amend all these things, greeting your Eminence I demand of you that you suffer them to be done no more; but straightly order him to abstain from harming the Church, and that none be aggrieved by burdens laid upon them, or payments, beyond what reason allows, and that, if there should be any suits, they be determined not by the terror of power, but by order of law.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 41:8
verses.text: I pray you, then, so correct all these things, the Lord inspiring you, by the menace of your injunction that the glorious Theodorus and his men may abstain from such things, if not out of regard to rectitude, yet at any rate out of fear inspired by your command; that so, to the advancement of your credit and reward, justice with liberty may flourish in the parts committed to your charge.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 42

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 42:1
verses.text: Epistle LXII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 42:2
verses.text: To Januarius, Archbishop of Caralis (Cagliari) in Sardinia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 42:3
verses.text: Gregory to Januarius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 42:4
verses.text: If our Lord Himself by the testimony of Holy Scripture declares Himself to be the husband of widows and father of orphans, we also, the members of His body, ought with the soul's supreme affection to set ourselves to imitate the head, and saving justice, to stand by orphans and widows if need be.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 42:5
verses.text: And, having been given to understand that Catella, a religious woman who has a son serving here in the holy Roman Church over which under God we preside, is being troubled by the exactions and molestations of certain persons, we think it needful to exhort your Fraternity by this letter not to refuse (saving justice) to afford your protection to this same woman, knowing that by things of this kind you both make the Lord your debtor and bind us to you the more in the bonds of charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 42:6
verses.text: For we wish the causes of the aforesaid woman, whether now or in future, to be terminated by your judgment, that she may be relieved from the annoyance of legal proceedings, and yet be by no means excused from submitting to a just judgment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 42:7
verses.text: Now I pray the Lord to direct your life in a prosperous course towards Himself, and Himself to bring you in His mercy to the kingdom of glory which is to come.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 43

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 43:1
verses.text: Epistle LXIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 43:2
verses.text: To Januarius, Bishop of Caralis (Cagliari) in Sardinia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 43:3
verses.text: Gregory to Januarius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 43:4
verses.text: Though your Fraternity in the zeal of righteousness  gives fitting attention to the protection of divers persons, yet we believe that you will be the more prone to succour those whom a letter from us may commend to you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 43:5
verses.text: Know then that Pompeiana, a religious woman, has represented to us through one of her people that she endures many grievances continually and unreasonably from certain men, and on this account has petitioned us to commend her in our letters to you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 43:6
verses.text: Wherefore, greeting your Fraternity with the affection of charity that is due to you, we have felt that we must needs commend the aforesaid woman to you, that, with due regard to justice, thy Fraternity may not allow her to be aggrieved in any way contrary to equity, or to be subjected to any expense unadvisedly.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 43:7
verses.text: But if it should happen that she has any suits, let the matter of dispute be debated before chosen arbitrators, and whatsoever shall be decided, let it be so carried into effect quietly through your assistance that both reward may accrue to you for such a work, and she who has been commended by our letters may rejoice in having found justice.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 44

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 44:1
verses.text: Epistle LXVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 44:2
verses.text: To Felix, Bishop of Messana (Messene).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 44:3
verses.text: Gregory to Felix, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 44:4
verses.text: Customs which are found to bring a burden upon churches it becomes us in our consideration to discontinue, lest any should be forced to contribute to quarters from which they ought rather to look for contributions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 44:5
verses.text: Accordingly, it is thy duty to preserve intact the custom of the clergy and others, and to transmit to them every year what has been accustomed: but for the future we forbid thee to transmit anything to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 44:6
verses.text: And, since we take no delight in presents (xeniis), we have received with thanks the Palmatianae which thy Fraternity has sent us, but have caused them to be sold for an adequate price, which we have transmitted separately to thy Fraternity, for fear lest thou shouldest have felt the expense.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 44:7
verses.text: Further, since we have learnt that thy Charity is desirous of coming to us, we admonish thee by the present letter not to take the trouble of coming: but pray for us, that the more we are separated by length of way, the more we may be joined one to another in mind, with the help of Christ, by charity; to the end that, aiding each other by mutual supplication, we may resign our office unimpaired to the Judge that is to come.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 45

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 45:1
verses.text: Epistle LXVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 45:2
verses.text: To Peter, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 45:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 45:4
verses.text: If with kind disposition we meet the needs of our neighbours by shewing compassion, we shall undoubtedly find the Lord mercifully inclined to our petitions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 45:5
verses.text: Now we have learnt that Pastor, who labours under exceeding weakness of sight, having a wife and two slaves, who also had formerly been with the glorious lady Jonatha, is suffering from great need.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 45:6
verses.text: Wherefore, we admonish thy Experience, by the writing of this present order, not to delay giving him for his sustenance three hundred modii of wheat, and also as many modii of beans, which may afterwards be charged in thy accounts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 45:7
verses.text: So act, then, as both thyself to obtain the benefit of reward for thy good service, and to carry our orders into effect.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 45:8
verses.text: In the month of August.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:1
verses.text: Epistle LXXII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:2
verses.text: To Peter, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:4
verses.text: Thou hast learnt from a former letter that we have desired our brethren and fellow-bishops dwelling in the island of Sicily to assemble here for the anniversary of the blessed Peter the apostle.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:5
verses.text: But, seeing that their suit with the magnificent Justin the ex-praetor has meanwhile hindered them, and that there is not now sufficient time for coming and returning, we do not wish them to be troubled before winter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:6
verses.text: But Gregory of Agrigentum, Leo of Catana, and Victor of Panormus, we by all means desire to come to us before winter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:7
verses.text: Further, get together from strangers corn of this year's growth to the value of fifty pounds of gold, and lay it up in Sicily in places where it will not rot, that we may send thither in the month of February as many ships as we can to convey this corn to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:8
verses.text: But, in case of our delaying to send ships, do thou thyself provide some, and, with the help of the Lord, transmit this same corn to us in February, with the exception, however, of the  corn which we expect to have sent to us now, according to custom, in the months of September or October.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:9
verses.text: Let thy Experience, then, so proceed that, without annoyance to any husbandman (colonus) of the Church, the corn may be collected, since there has been here such a scanty crop that, unless by God's help corn be collected from Sicily, there is a serious prospect of famine.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:10
verses.text: But keep guard in all ways over the ships that have always been assigned to the use of Holy Church, as the letters also addressed to thee by the glorious ex-consul Leo concur in directing thee to do.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:11
verses.text: Moreover, many come hither desiring sundry lands or islands belonging to our Church to be leased to them; and some, indeed, we refuse, but to others we have already granted their request.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:12
verses.text: But let thy Experience see to the advantage of Holy Church, remembering that thou hast before the most sacred body of the blessed apostle Peter received power over his patrimony.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 46:13
verses.text: And, though letters should reach you from hence, allow nothing to be done in any way to the disadvantage of the patrimony, since we neither remember to have given, nor are disposed to give away, any thing without good reason.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:1
verses.text: Epistle LXXIV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:2
verses.text: To Gennadius, Patrician and Exarch of Africa.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:3
verses.text: Gregory to Gennadius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:4
verses.text: As the Lord hath made your Excellency to shine with the light of victories in the military wars of this life, so ought you to pose the enemies of the Church with all activity of mind and body, to the end that from both kinds of triumph your reputation may shine forth more and more, when in forensic wars, too, you firmly resist the adversaries of the Catholic Church in behalf of the Christian people, and bravely fight ecclesiastical battles as warriors of the Lord.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:5
verses.text: For it is known that men heretical in religion, if they have liberty allowed them to do harm (which God forbid), rise strenuously against the catholic faith, to the end that they may transfuse, if they can, the poison of their heresy to the corrupting of the members of the Christian body.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:6
verses.text: For we have learnt that they are lifting up their necks against the Catholic Church, the Lord being opposed to them, and desire to pervert the faith of the Christian profession.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:7
verses.text: But let your Eminence suppress their attempts, and subdue their proud necks to the yoke of rectitude.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:8
verses.text: Moreover, order the council of catholic bishops to be admonished not to appoint their primate on the ground of his standing, without regard to the merits of his life, since before God it is not the more distinguished rank, but the action of a better life, that is approved.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:9
verses.text: But let the primate himself live, not, as is customary, here and there in the country, but in one city according to their selection, to the end that he may be better able to bring to bear the influence of the dignity that has fallen to him in resisting the Donatists.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:10
verses.text: Moreover, if any from the Council of Numidia should desire to come to the Apostolic See, permit them to do so; and stop any who may be disposed to bring charges against their character.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:11
verses.text: Great increase of glory will accrue to your Excellency with the Creator, if through you the union of the divided churches could be restored.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:12
verses.text: For when He beholds the gifts granted by Him given back to His glory, He bestows gifts so much the more abundantly as He sees the dignity of His religion to be thereby enlarged.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 47:13
verses.text: Furthermore, bestowing on you, as is due, the affection of our paternal charity, we beseech the Lord to make your arm strong for subduing your enemies, and to sharpen your soul with zeal for the faith like the edge of a quivering sword.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:1
verses.text: Epistle LXXV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:2
verses.text: To Gennadius, Patrician, and Exarch throughout Africa.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:3
verses.text: Gregory to Gennadius, Patrician, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:4
verses.text: Had not such great success of the military exploits of your Excellency arisen from the merit of your faith and from the grace of the Christian religion, it would not have been so greatly to be wondered at, since we know that the like has been granted to military leaders of old time.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:5
