verses.text: But when, God granting it, you forestall future victories, not by carnal provision, but rather by prayers, it becomes a matter of astonishment how your glory comes down upon you,  not from counsels of this world, but from God, who bestows it from above.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:6
verses.text: For where is not the renown of your deserts in people's mouths? And report goes that it is not from a desire of shedding blood that you constantly court these wars, but for the sake of extending the republic in which we see that God is worshipped, to the end that the name of Christ may be spread abroad through subject nations by preaching of the faith.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:7
verses.text: For, as your outward deeds of valour make you eminent in this life, so also the inward adornment of your character, proceeding from a clean heart, glorifies you in making you partaker of celestial joys to come.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:8
verses.text: For we have learnt that your Excellency has done very many things of advantage for feeding the sheep of the blessed Peter, Prince of the apostles, so as to have restored to him no small portions of his patrimony, which had been denuded of their proper cultivators, by supplying them with Datitian settlers.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:9
verses.text: Whatever, then, with Christian disposition you confer on him, you receive retribution for through hope in the judgment to come.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:10
verses.text: Wherefore we have thought fit to commend to your Eminence Hilarus, who is also the hearer of these presents, that you may bestow on him (though ever with regard to justice) your accustomed affection in matters wherein he may intimate his need of your help.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 48:11
verses.text: Now, addressing to you the greeting of our paternal charity, we beseech our God and Saviour mercifully to protect your Eminence for the consolation of the holy republic, and to fortify you with the strength of His arm for spreading His name more and more through the neighbouring nations.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:1
verses.text: Epistle LXXVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:2
verses.text: To All the Bishops of Numidia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:3
verses.text: Gregory to all the Bishops of Numidia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:4
verses.text: If ever, most dear brethren in Christ, a troublesome mixture of tares intrudes itself among green corn, it is necessary for the hand of the husbandman to root it up entirely, lest the future fruit of the fertile corn should be obstructed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:5
verses.text: Wherefore let us too, who, however unworthy, have undertaken the cultivation of the field of the Lord, hasten to render the corn pure from all offence of tares, that the field of the Lord may fructify with more abundant increase.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:6
verses.text: Now you requested through Hilarus our chartulary from our predecessor of blessed memory that you might retain all the customs of past time, which, from the beginnings of the ordinances of the blessed Peter, Prince of the apostles, long antiquity has so far retained.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:7
verses.text: And we, indeed, according to the tenour of your representation, allow your custom (so long as it clearly makes no claim to the prejudice of the catholic faith) to remain undisturbed, whether as to constituting primates or as to other points; save that with respect to those who attain to the episcopate from among the Donatists, we by all means forbid them to be advanced to the dignity of primacy, even though their standing should denote them for that position.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:8
verses.text: But let it suffice them to take care of the people committed to them, without aiming at the topmost place of the primacy in preference to those prelates whom the Catholic faith hath both taught and engendered in the bosom of the Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:9
verses.text: Do you, therefore, most dear brethren, anticipate our admonitions in the zeal of the charity of the Lord, knowing that the strict Judge will bring into examination all we do, and will approve every one of us with regard not to the prerogative of a higher rank, but to the merits of our works.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:10
verses.text: I beseech you, therefore, love ye one another mutually, having peace among yourselves in Christ, and with one purpose of heart oppose ye heretics and enemies of the Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:11
verses.text: Be ye solicitous for the souls of your neighbours: persuade all ye can to faith by the preaching of charity, holding before them also the terror of the future judgment; inasmuch as ye are appointed to be shepherds, and the Lord of the flocks expects from the shepherds to whom He has committed them the fruit of a multiplied flock.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:12
verses.text: And if He should foresee an augmentation of His own flock through your bestowal of more diligent care upon it, He will assuredly adorn you with manifold gifts of the heavenly kingdom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 49:13
verses.text: Furthermore, addressing to you the greeting of fraternal love, I pray the Lord that He would make you, whom He has chosen to be shepherds of souls, worthy in His sight, and Himself so order our deeds here that He may accept them as they deserve in the future life.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50:1
verses.text: Epistle LXXVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50:2
verses.text: To Leo, Bishop in Corsica.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50:3
verses.text: Gregory to Leo, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50:4
verses.text: Our pastoral charge constrains us to come with anxious consideration to the succour of a church that is destitute of the control of a priest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50:5
verses.text: And, inasmuch as we have learnt  that the church of Saona for many years, since the death of its pontiff, has been thus entirely destitute, we have thought it needful to enjoin on thy Fraternity the work of visiting it, to the end that through thy ordering its welfare may be promoted.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50:6
verses.text: In this church also and in its parishes we grant thee licence to ordain deacons and presbyters; concerning whom, however, let it be thy care to make diligent enquiry, that they be not personally in any respect such as are rejected by the sacred canons.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50:7
verses.text: But whomsoever thy Fraternity has perceived to be worthy of so great a ministry, having ascertained that their manners and actions fit them for ordination, them, by permission of our authority, thou mayest freely promote to the aforesaid office.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50:8
verses.text: We desire thee, therefore, to make use of all the property of the above named church as though thou wert its proper pontiff, until we write to thee again.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 50:9
verses.text: Be, then, so diligent and careful in all these matters that through thy ordering all things may, with the help of God, be salubriously arranged to the Church's profit.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 51

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 51:1
verses.text: Epistle LXXIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 51:2
verses.text: To Martinus, Bishop in Corsica.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 51:3
verses.text: Gregory to Martinus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 51:4
verses.text: To those who ask for what is just it behoves us to lend a kindly ear, to the end both that the petitioners may find the remedies they hope for, and that the anxious care of a shepherd be not wanting to the Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 51:5
verses.text: And inasmuch as the church of Tanates, in which thy Fraternity was formerly adorned with sacerdotal dignity, has for its sins been so taken possession of and ruined by hostile savagery that no further hope remains of thy returning thither, we appoint thee, by authority of these presents, undisputed cardinal priest in the Church of Saona, which has now been long deprived of the aid of a pontiff.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 51:6
verses.text: Do thou therefore so arrange and order all things according to the injunctions of the canons with vigilant care in the love of God, that both thy Fraternity may rejoice in having attained thy desires, and the Church of God may be filled with answering joy for having received thee as Cardinal pontiff.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 52

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 52:1
verses.text: Epistle LXXX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 52:2
verses.text: To the Clergy and Nobles of Corsica.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 52:3
verses.text: Gregory to the Clergy, &cA paribus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 52:4
verses.text: Although for a long time it has caused you no sorrow that the Church of God should be without a pontiff, yet as for us, we are both compelled by the charge of the office we bear and bound especially by the charity of our love for you, to take thought for its government, knowing that in its supervision lies at the same time advantage to your souls.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 52:5
verses.text: For, if the care of a shepherd be wanting to a flock, it easily falls into the snares of the lier in wait.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 52:6
verses.text: Accordingly, inasmuch as the church of Saona has long been deprived of the aid of a priest, we have held it necessary to constitute Martinus, our brother and fellow-bishop, cardinal priest of the same, but to enjoin on Leo our brother and fellow-bishop the work of its visitation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 52:7
verses.text: To the latter we have also granted licence to ordain presbyters and deacons in it and in its parishes, and have permitted him to make use of its property so long as be shall be there, as though he were its proper pontiff.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles I 52:8
verses.text: And so we admonish you by these present writings that your Charity receive the aforesaid visitor with all devotion, and shew him obedience in whatever is reasonable, as becomes sons of the Church, to the end that, supported by your devotion, he may be able to accomplish all that is found to conduce to the advantage of the above-named church.
